author: smartdesign

title: F-18 - Scaled Model with Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Impress your buddies with this Bad-A** F-18 Model. It's a 1/125th scale model of the real thing. To make it 'printable' WITHOUT SUPPORT, I've broken it up into three pieces that will need to be glued together. To download, visit my github:
https://github.com/beardface/3D/tree/master/Planes/F18

1) Print all the parts
2) Glue together
3) Impress friends by putting on your flight jacket while you drink at the local watering hole while singing great balls of fire
4) ...
5) Profit? I printed this with the following: Mendel Prusa, v2
3mm .5 BudaSchnozzle Hot End, Black Filament
Slic3r 8.4.0 2.0mm Layer Height
2 perimiters, 3 solid layers, .5 fill density I used a Brim of 10mm to make sure i had 0 warping Printed at 50mm/s Took me about 6 hours total print time. **For those that think they can do a better job slicing this... I've uploaded a full stl for the f18...

I designed these stands because all of the Xbox One X stands that I found are too large to be printed on my printer. author: ampinto828

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B X Axis

description.text:
(please feel welcome to check out, all of my other designs under my profile :P https://www.thingiverse.com/The_Craft_Dude/designs )

Since i wanted to upgrade the X axis on my Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B with some 3d printed parts that was not all flimsy, so i came up with this.

  • The parts got mounts for 2 endstops (X min and X max)

  • Adjustable Z endstop screw mount, for those who might be using longer or shorter screws.

  • A hole for the nut on the Z endstop screw mount, so it is easier to dial in then most 3d printed parts.

  • Mounted the Z screw nut mounts higher up, to accommodate both for long couplings, anti backlash nuts+springs and help to reduce Z wobble at the lower layers.

(please note, i have yet not printed and tested these parts yet, but they are based on the original purse mk2 parts, but you are printing these, please let me know, if there is anything you want to be changed)

title: RJ4JP Split Carrier V2 - M4 Nut - Fits SC8UU Mount

description.text:
Please consider leaving a tip or donating via paypal on my website: http://ferociousdesigns.co.uk/ if you like this design! All support is very much appreciated!

A new version of the RJ4JP split carrier which can hold an Igus RJ4JP-01-08 bearing and mount in place of the SC8UU bearing block. It is lighter and does not need circlips due to the split design.

Printed with 25% cubic infill and 0.2mm layers.

You require 4 x M4 nuts for each block and need to print 2 halves. You should be able to use the original M4 bolts from the SC8UU but I have made allowance for longer bolts as the holes go right through the blocks.

I have remade the model from scratch but still attribute the original idea to Crashc0de :)

title: KAP-RIG - PETG - Konstruktion  Version 2018-01-29
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KAP-RIG - Konstruktion

Version 2018-01-29

Dieses KAP-RIG wurde mit PETG-Material auf einen Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro B geruckt.
Düsengröße 0,3 mm
Schichtdicke: 0,1 mm
Linenbreite / Wandliniebreite 0,4 mm
Wanddicke 1,2 mm
Füllung 50% - Gitter mit 25% Überlappung
Druckplattenhaftung - Skirt

Zusätzlich werden folgende Teile benötigt.

  • M3 Schrauben 10mm (18x)
  • M3 Schrauben 25mm (1x)
  • M3 Muttern (19x)
  • M3 Unterlegscheiben (19x)
  • M2 Schrauben Kunststoff 20mm (8x)
  • M2 Muttern 6mm (8x)
  • M2 Muttern (8x)
  • Step-Motor Typ 28BYJ-48 (1x)
  • Step-Motor-Treiber Typ ULN2003 (1x)
  • Servo-Motor Typ AS-215 BBMG (1x)
  • Servo-Motor Typ SG-90 (1x)
  • Stativschraube (1x)
  • Arduino-Nano (1x)
  • Lochrasterplatine (1x)
  • Dip-Schalter 8-fach (1x)
  • Optokopler Typ TLP621 (2x)
  • USB-Kabel (1x)
  • Pfostenleiste (1x)
  • Ein-Aus-Schalter (1x)
  • IR-LED (1x)
  • Powerbank mit 2A Ausgang (1x)

Für die Drehung um die Vertikalachse wird ein Step-Motor (Typ 28BYJ-48) benutzt.
Für die Drehung um die Horizontalachse wird ein Servo-Motor (Typ AS-215BBMG) benutzt.
Für die Kameraauslösung wird ein entweder ein Servo-Motor (Typ SG-90) benutzt oder eine IR-LED.

Das KAP-RIG wird mit einem Arduino-Nano gesteuert.
Das Steuerungsprogramm enthält ausführliche Kommentare.
Mit den Dip-Schaltern kann die Drehung und Neigung des KAP-RIG eingestellt werden.

Drehung: Die Drehung der Kamera kann ueber die DIP-Schalter eingestellt werden.
DIP 1: OFF; DIP 2: OFF = Das RIG wird um 360 Grad gedreht, bei einer Neigung von 90 Grad. Sind andere Winkel aktiviert wird auch hier eine 360 Grad Drehung vollzogen. Es findet keinen Ausloesung der Kamera statt (Videomodus).
DIP 1: OFF; DIP 2: ON = Das RIG wird in 10,019 Grad Winkelschritten gedreht, bei einer Neigung von 90 Grad. Sind andere Winkel aktiviert werden diese angefahren und danach weitergedreht. Die Kamera wird ausgeloest.
DIP 2: ON; DIP 2: OFF = Das RIG wird in 20,039 Grad Winkelschritten gedreht, bei einer Neigung von 90 Grad. Sind andere Winkel aktiviert werden diese angefahren und danach weitergedreht. Die Kamera wird ausgeloest.
DIP 2: ON; DIP 2: ON = Das RIG wird in 30,058 Grad Winkelschritten gedreht, bei einer Neigung von 90 Grad. Sind andere Winkel aktiviert werden diese angefahren und danach weitergedreht. Die Kamera wird ausgeloest.

Neigungswinkel:
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: OFF = (B000) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 Grad.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: ON = (B001) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 und 68 Grad.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: OFF = (B010) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 und 46 Grad.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: ON = (B011) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 , 68 und 46 Grad.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: OFF = (B100) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 und 24 Grad.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: ON = (B101) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 , 68 und 24 Grad.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: OFF = (B110) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 , 46 und 24 Grad.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: ON = (B111) = Die RIG-Neigung faehrt auf 90 , 68, 46 und 24 Grad.

Pause: Nach jedem der drei Dreh-Winkelschritte und der RIG-Neigung wird eine Pause gemacht. Bei der fortlaufenden Drehung (360 Grad) wird keine Pause gemacht.
DIP 6: OFF; DIP 7: OFF = Pausenzeit von 3 Sekunden bei IR-LED bzw. Kabelauslösung und 6 Sekunden bei Servoauslösung.
DIP 6: OFF; DIP 7: ON = Pausenzeit von 6 Sekunden bei IR-LED bzw. Kabelauslösung und 12 Sekunden bei Servoauslösung.
DIP 6: ON; DIP 7: OFF = Pausenzeit von 6 Sekunden bei IR-LED bzw. Kabelauslösung und 10 Sekunden bei Servoauslösung.
DIP 6: ON; DIP 7: ON = Pausenzeit von 12 Sekunden bei IR-LED bzw. Kabelauslösung und 20 Sekunden bei Servoauslösung.

Ausloesen:
DIP 8: OFF = Die Kamera wird ueber eine IR-LED bzw. einen Kabelausloeser ausgeloest.
DIP 8: ON = Die Kamera wird ueber einen Servo ausgeloest.

Viel Spaß mit dem KAP-RIG
Thorsten Jahn

KAP-RIG - construction

Version 2018-01-29

This KAP-RIG was printed with PETG material on a Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro B.
Nozzle size 0.3 mm
Layer thickness: 0.1 mm
Line width / wall line width 0.4 mm
Wall thickness 1.2 mm
Filling 50% - grid with 25% overlap
Pressure plate adhesion - Skirt

In addition, the following parts are required.

  • M3 screws 10mm (18x)
  • M3 screws 25mm (1x)
  • M3 nuts (19x)
  • M3 washers (19x)
  • M2 screws plastic 20mm (8x)
  • M2 nuts 6mm (8x)
  • M2 nuts (8x)
  • Step motor type 28BYJ-48 (1x)
  • Step motor driver type ULN2003 (1x)
  • servo motor type AS-215 BBMG (1x)
  • Servo motor type SG-90 (1x)
  • Tripod screw (1x)
  • Arduino-Nano (1x)
  • breadboard (1x)
  • dip-switch 8-fold (1x)
  • Optocoupler type TLP621 (2x)
  • USB cable (1x)
  • Post bar (1x)
  • On-off switch (1x)
  • IR LED (1x)
  • Powerbank with 2A output (1x)

For rotation around the vertical axis, a step motor (type 28BYJ-48) is used.
For rotation around the horizontal axis a servo motor (type AS-215BBMG) is used.
For the camera release, either a servo motor (type SG-90) or an IR LED is used.

The KAP-RIG is controlled by an Arduino-Nano.
The control program contains detailed comments.
With the dip switches the rotation and inclination of the KAP-RIG can be adjusted.

Rotation: The rotation of the camera can be adjusted via the DIP switches.
DIP 1: OFF; DIP 2: OFF = The RIG is rotated 360 degrees at a 90 degree incline. If other angles are activated, a 360 degree turn is made here as well. There is no release of the camera (video mode).
DIP 1: OFF; DIP 2: ON = The RIG is rotated in 10,019 degree increments at a 90 degree incline. If other angles are activated, they are approached and then further rotated. The camera is triggered.
DIP 2: ON; DIP 2: OFF = The RIG is rotated in 20.039 degree increments, at a 90 degree incline. If other angles are activated, they are approached and then further rotated. The camera is triggered.
DIP 2: ON; DIP 2: ON = The RIG is rotated in 30,058 degree increments at a 90 degree incline. If other angles are activated, they are approached and then further rotated. The camera is triggered.

Inclination:
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: OFF = (B000) = RIG tilt is 90 degrees.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: ON = (B001) = RIG tilt is 90 and 68 degrees.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: OFF = (B010) = RIG tilt is 90 degrees and 46 degrees.
DIP 3: OFF; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: ON = (B011) = RIG tilt is 90, 68 and 46 degrees.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: OFF = (B100) = The RIG tilt goes to 90 and 24 degrees.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: OFF; DIP 5: ON = (B101) = RIG tilt is 90, 68 and 24 degrees.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: OFF = (B110) = RIG tilt is 90, 46 and 24 degrees.
DIP 3: ON; DIP 4: ON; DIP 5: ON = (B111) = RIG tilt is 90, 68, 46 and 24 degrees.

Pause: After each of the three rotation-angle steps and the RIG tilt, a break is made. Continuous rotation (360 degrees) will not pause.
DIP 6: OFF; DIP 7: OFF = pause time of 3 seconds with IR LED or cable release and 6 seconds with servo release.
DIP 6: OFF; DIP 7: ON = pause time of 6 seconds with IR LED or cable release and 12 seconds with servo release.
DIP 6: ON; DIP 7: OFF = pause time of 6 seconds with IR-LED or cable release and 10 seconds with servo release.
DIP 6: ON; DIP 7: ON = pause time of 12 seconds with IR-LED or cable release and 20 seconds with servo release.

Trigger:
DIP 8: OFF = The camera is triggered via an IR LED or a cable release.
DIP 8: ON = The camera is triggered by a servo.

Have fun with the KAP-RIG
Thorsten Jahn

author: httpkoopa

description.text:
The Tarkin, or the Tarkin Project, was an Imperial superweapon modeled in principle after the first Death Star battlestation and named in honor of the late Grand Moff Wilhuff Tarkin. The Tarkin combined the first Death Star's offensive capabilities in the form of a planet-destroying ionic cannon superlaser with a defensive shield generator and a set of engines. Imperial engineer Bevel Lemelisk designed the Tarkin, at the behest of Emperor Palpatine following the Death Star's destruction at the Battle of Yavin, as a prototype weapons testbed for the construction of the Eclipse-class Super Star Destroyer, a massive warship armed with a ship-mounted superlaser.

More details to the bridge and general body to come later ...

author: N1337XYZ

description.text:
Based on the great idea of RichRap:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769823

This is a lasercut version of the masterspool.

I chose a design of 3 single parts for the following reasons:

  1. Reduction of printing time.
  2. Less filament.
  3. Simple 3D printing, especially for smaller printers.
  4. Flexible roll width by simple extrusion of the core drum.

Disadvantage:
In addition to the 3D printer, you also need a laser cutter.
The two side parts can also be produced with the router, CNC milling machine, jigsaw, etc.

The 3d printing part has become very simple. Every printer can produce it.

Material:
For the core:
approx. 85g filament at 15% filling, printing time 3-4h

The two side parts:
5mm plexiglass, acrylic, MDF etc.

3x M5x65 (70) or M6x65 (70) alternatively threaded rod
3 butterfly valves M5 or M6

All holes for M6 screws. M5 would be enough. But it's easier to get M6 in length.

Example for filament manufacturer (in Germany)

https://www.dasfilament.de/filament-refill/pla-1-75-mm/283/pla-filament-1-75-mm-kirschrot-refill-850-g?c=52

This design is for a 850g roll with 46..47mm width and an inside radius of 102mm.
I hope there are rolls with 2..3kg filament soon.
I will adapt the design then.
The inner drum can be easily adjusted by extrusion in the slicer.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,3mm

Infill:

15%

title: Various Organic Structure Trivets cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Unlike my earlier publication of a trivet these structures are of complete procedural origin, no tracing or pixel manipulation of any kind was involved. I used Illustrator and some very cool scripts by Hiroyuki Sato to create various organic structures.

  • voronoi_from_selected_objects.jsx
  • Round Any Corner.jsx
  • Archimedean Spiral.jsx
  • circlepacking_in_a_circle.jsx

To make these trivets I used my entry-level cnc and some 6 mm birch and beech plywood. To prevent the very bright birch wood from burn marks if used with a really hot pan I veneered smoked oak on one surface.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create one like this. I have even seen some scaled down prints.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Household-Items/Trivets for more interesting trivet designs.

print_settings.Notes:: I used heavier infill due to strength concerns. You can try lower if you want faster prints, just be gentle when inserting the ball to the frame.

description.text:
Hi all! This is my first "big" upload to Thingiverse. I have a few things, but none that I spent time with revisions and edits. I found this to be a very useful and well received design. If you don't mind, please give me a like. If you feel inspired, please consider tipping. I know, I'm not as prolific as some, but any motivation to keep me going is much appreciated! Also, I'd love to see other people's prints / builds with this design. If you have pictures, please share!

Orientation matters. For strength, I printed the layers normal to the ball axis. Sanding may be required on the spherical surfaces for smoother sliding. The Igus bearings have grooves; I used o-rings to retain the bearing into the ball, but a retaining ring would be better.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

I used heavier infill due to strength concerns. You can try lower if you want faster prints, just be gentle when inserting the ball to the frame.

Software

This was designed in Fusion 360. The photos show the original printed iteration. The clamping tabs interfered with the frame and threaded rod, so I shifted those and opened some tolerances for the bearing and ball. I have not printed the update, so please let me know if you do and find issues or ideas for improvement.

It is also important to note that these, in my configuration, raised the print bed by approximately 10.5 mm. This might be an issue for an otherwise stock setup. Please review your build and adjust accordingly.

The newer files labeled "final" improve the offset a bit, but only by a few mm. Please check your setup to make sure you're ok with the lost z-height due to this offset! The tolerances are also very generous. I don't like how loose everything looks, but when I print it, things fit well. My original tolerances came out much too tight. I'm sure it's my printer and settings, so please check your set up and files to make sure this will fit and function when assembled.

Files Update

I finally uploaded what I will consider to be final files. This build has worked well for me, and I'm ready to move on to other build needs. If you find issues with my files, or have suggestions for improvement, please let me know!

Oh, and I used the Render functionality in Fusion 360 for the first time with this one. Let me know what you think!

This is OpenSCAD source for a geneva mechanism.  Most parts are parametric, so you can adjust the radius of the moon wheel, the number of slots in the star wheel, etc.
The source is public domain.

For an interesting demo, you should be able to print both of the STL files, and then snap the wheels onto the base. The OpenSCAD source defines the following useful stuff: module geneva_wheel():
Used to create matching moon & star wheels for a geneva mechanism.
e.g., Make a moon wheel: geneva_wheel(star:false, count:5, moon_radius:30);
Make a star wheel: geneva_wheel(star:true, count:5, moon_radius:30); See the module definition for other supported arguments. function geneva_center_distance():
Returns the proper center distance between wheels, based on the pitch radius of the moon wheel, and the notch count of the star wheel.
e.g., geneva_center_distance(moon_radius:30, count:5) function geneva_star_radius():
Returns the radius of the star wheel matching the given moon wheel pitch radius, and star wheel notch count.
e.g., geneva_star_radius(moon_radius:30, count:5) function geneva_moon_outer_radius(moon_radius, pin_diameter)
Returns the outer radius of the moon wheel, given the pitch radius and pin diameter.
e.g., geneva_moon_outer_radius(moon_radius:30, pin_diameter:5)

title: TPU Cap for Screwless Filament Feeder

description.text:
Cap for Screwless Filament Feeder - 1.75

I'd like to thank Sreisig1 for making the Screwless Filament Feeder, out of all the drybox ports I've found his is the most simple and compact.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1750875

I'll start off by saying that this part is expected to be printed in a flexible filament like TPU, I don't know if it will even work printed in rigid filament because I never tried.

While building my drybox I discovered that I had a mix of spool widths, so to be able to accommodate the maximum variety of spools in my drybox I decided to put 9 ports in the side of my box. The problem I immediately had was I didn't have nine narrow spools to put in the box and now I had openings that allowed humidity in. So I sat down and built this part, when printed in TPU it fits snugly over the hex head of the port and sits completely flush with the box. The center post actually gets larger at the base to help ensure a tight fit.

I have also attached the SketchUp file in case anyone needs to modify it or make something else completely awesome from it.

The other cap you see in the picture attached to the PTFE tube was made by Lichtzeichenanlage and you can find it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2459359

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This needs to be printed with a flexible filament like TPU, I have no idea if it will even work if printed with a rigid filament. I can almost guarantee that you will have problems printing the very top of the center post unless you either slow down your prints dramatically during that part or do as I did and just print a few at a time so it gives each part time to cool between layers.

author: zuluvape

description.text:
Make sure to download both files - one is the phone mount, the other is what holds the phone mount on the top of the transmitter with 2 M3 15+mm screws and 2 M3 ny-lock nuts

So I couldn't find a phone mount for my Traxxas TQi remote, so I made this. This only works with iPhone 8+ (maybe not 6+ or 7+ because of mount thickness) because I don't have those phones to test this with.

This model may have some errors because I do not have a 3D printer at the moment to test this with, so y'all will have to tell me what to fix (for now). If this model gets enough support, I will try to make this mount compatible with other phones.

You will need 2 M3 15+mm screws and 2 M3 nuts (preferably ny-lock nuts). (Doesn't matter what head it is, but I prefer hex heads)

Mount this to the top handle of the TQ / TQi remote and bolt this down tight enough to where it will not move around (it may swivel around, but that might be helpful too for viewing your phone at different angles). I would use a hex key at a 90° angle because the bolts may be hard to get to. The holes are 2.9mm in diameter, and if you need them to be larger let me know.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a remix of the Nautilus Gears by David_L_G that I created to allow easier printing with PETG.

The original design has a very thin perimeter profile that the teeth connect to which was causing issues with my printer as each individual tooth has a triangle that would print first before printing the outside edge of the gear and the PETG just would not lay down with the tiny triangles. I increased the perimeter thickness so that the inner and outer lines would print first and then the center would fill in afterward. I also remixed the tie bars to be open and thinner to allow more visibility to the gears and bearings.

I also corrected the center of the gears to be 22mm as that is the size of my 608 bearings. The original design has 3 different options and even the tightest was too big for the bearings.

Printing in PETG helps the gears feel less harsh to the fingers than PLA or ABS and they are nearly silent when they spin. I removed the chamber lines to keep the weight of the gear on the outer edge which I found helps the gears spin much faster. Printing with 1.2 layer and shell size and 20-25 infill gives it more weight so the gears will spin better.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have a Monoprice Maker Select Plus printer which is a copy of the Wanhao I3 Plus. I printed this out using 1.2 shell, 1.2 top/bottom and 15mm/s for all print speeds to reduce stringing with the PETG filament.

description.text:
This is a simple stand to keep my old Macbook from resting on the table. When it rests down on the table cloth the fan starts running and will not stop as it over heats. With this stand the airflow underneath is improved so the fan doesn't have to go crazy. It also positions the keys a little better for typing. I just wanted something quick and simple that would keep it off the table surface. I didn't want to create an assembly of parts so I hollowed out the block. I printed this with no supports but you could certainly use supports if you are worried about the aesthetic qualities. I have a Macbook Pro 15" and it doesn't wobble on this stand.

If you make one please post a picture as it's always great to see what other people do with it.

author: broodforce

description.text:
Voici un petit test de calibration pour votre première couche d'impression (First layer height). C'est simplement 2 feuille de plastique une de 0.2 et l'autre de 0.3

Il est conseiller d'avoir un outils de mesure précis pour optimiser les résultats, mais on peut quand même voir a l’œil si c’est bien ou non. Moi j'utilise un pied à coulisse numérique.

Le but de la manœuvre est d'imprimer les test selon leur épaisseur. Il faut donc aller ajusté les paramètre du slicer .. exemple dans repetier-host : Printer Settings - layers and perimeters - Layer height - First layer height .. vous mettez 0.2 ou 0.3 dépendamment du test que vous imprimé. Une fois imprimé, vous mesuré et ajusté. Il se peut que vous n'ayez pas besoin de refaire le niveau (leveling) vous pouvez simplement ajuster la hauteur de z
(zoffset). Si un côté est plus épais que l'autre alors la c'est probablement le niveau qui est a refaire (tout dépend de si c’est acceptable ou non).

Here we got a simple test for the first layer. This is 2 sheet of plastic 0.2 and 0.3 layer height. what you need to do is to print this with your layer height set to 0.2 or 0.3 and check if it printed right. You can mesure it with a calipers numeric if it print too big or too small you can ajuste the z offset , but if it more thick/slim for one side than the other you probably need to re-leveling.

Kossel 2020

comments.author: MCAction

description.text:
Recently I found a compact mosfet module called “Little Driver” by Digital Sqrt which is designed to switch the high current bed heater remote from the motherboard, which has the advantage of being able to connect the heater directly to the main power supply and not load the main board, which could cause transient pulse problems on the main board. The shorter wire runs and low impedance of the switch allows more power to be delivered to the bed and thus it will heat faster.

The module is far more compact than similar modules from China as is shown in one of the enclosed pictures, which shows this enclosure compared to the enclosure I designed for the Chinese module. I have designed an enclosure to house the “Little Driver” PCB which incorporates a 30mm x 10mm box fan (see picture) which impinges air directly on the mosfet chip. I like to provide 3M metal threads to secure the board into the housing by using pull rivet nuts (see picture) which I press fit into molded holes.

I designed the mounting to attach directly to the “2020” extruded rails that make up the base of most Kossel delta printers using M4x10 screws and M4 hammer T nuts. It can also be secured to any flat surface with suitable M4 or #6 hardware. The mounting holes are on a 40mm x 60mm rectangular pattern. If you need a SLIGHTLY different pattern to mount to existing holes, let me know through the comment section.

The “Little Driver” module is available from Digital Sqrt (digital-sqrt.com). The “Little Driver” board is very well documented on the Website. All other components are available from AliExpress.

Printer:

FLSUN big Kossel delta

any (I use 25%)

title: Two axle semi trailer dolly Tamiya 1/14 compatible

description.text:
A Minimalist Two Axle Trailer Dolly

Very basic, frame rails, tongue, fifth wheel plate and a rear bumper. Nothing extra here, but still some decent scale detail in the fifth wheel plate and frame rails that are strong enough even in PLA.

Tamiya hardware

This design has integrated mounting holes for the ubiquitous Tamiya two axle leaf spring suspension setup. There are options on thingiverse for printing most of these parts as well. The other parts that come from Tamiya kits are the fifth wheel itself, associated mounting hardware and the release mechanism. You can also obtain the rectangle taillight lenses from the flatbed kit and mudflaps or make your own.

Additional hardware needed

The front tongue is held on by 4mm battery bullet connectors and you'll need a few extra 3mm screws (the same as used in all Tamiya kits) to put the rest of it together. The rear bumper and the top plate use wood style threads and thread right into the rails. All other fasteners have a recessed hole for a flanged lock nut also used in Tamiya kits.

The tongue

The tongue is currently designed to leverage the rc4wd pintle hook mount. Its not the cheapest, but is pretty good looking and I think accurate for the style used in the US.

I like these for the hinge connectors: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/4mm-gold-connectors-low-profile-10pc.html

With that said, its fairly trivial to adapt the design to a different type of mount like a rod end. If you want a specific type of mount, post in the comments and I'll do my best to provide it and add it to the make, or you can load up that .stl into tinkercad and make it for yourself.

Feedback is welcome, happy making!

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk3

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Some supports can make the print cleaner on the rear bumper, although most printers can probably just bridge it.

I print the center support beams vertically with no supports, but I do use a gluestick for those as they have a small bed contact area and love to come loose.

To get the second frame rail simply load up the one provided and flip / mirror it in your slicer to get the other side.

Other than that, a pretty easy print.

author: Eficker

description.text: this is a replacement part for my knock off otter box case. mine broke and so i made a new one. printed in abs and works great.

It's almost Valentines Day and you're making Chocolate-Covered Strawberries for your sweetie. You melt the chocolate in a double-boiler, and try to dip in each berry. But they fall in, the leaves get coated and break off, and your fingers get sticky and covered with chocolate. You give up in frustration. But wait, there's a solution. Pluck off the leaves, skewer the berry, and just twist and dip away. Keep your finger clean and neat. Just use the Chocolate-Covered Strawberry Skewer

Technical notes: Design developed in FreeCAD. Print Handle section and Screw section pieces. Apply glue and fit handle section into screw section. Unskewer berries before eating. Hand wash. See "Is 3D Printed PLA food safe?" (https://reprage.com/post/36869678168/is-3d-printed-pla-food-safe) which states "The study found that PLA is Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) when used in contact with food.". Samples printed on Prusa i3 MK3 in PLA with 0.2 mm layer height.

Update 2018-02-18: Made hole in screw section larger to allow handle section to slide in easier. No press fit, and now gluing is required.

description.text:
The GPS Tracker TK102B is widely used. You get it for about $ 13 to $ 15.

The factory setting does not allow autostart. For some GPS trackers, I have bypassed the ON / OFF button (this is easily done by loosening the screw under the "QC PASSED" seal and taking the board out halfway).

Now I've made a shell that holds the ON / OFF button when plugged in. So the GPS Tracker always starts automatically when 5V USB voltage is applied.

It saves you almost pressing the button to start. To switch off the button must be pressed again.

In different colors you can keep track of different trackers!
The bow has become a bit ugly...

description.text:
Static mixer designed around gorilla 2 part 5 minute epoxy syringe. Still very much a work in progress and i would encourage others to download and improve on the included OpenSCAD file, as through several design iterations and tests, I have yet to accomplish a homogenous mixture coming out the end. As is, it requires much less stirring to achieve a thorough mixture throughout than without using the static mixer tube. Future versions will be uploaded here.

I am NOT putting it on here available as a customizer enabled design as it takes nearly 10 minutes to render in OpenSCAD locally, and there are a boat load of variables that can be monkied about with, so i feel it is better off being downloaded and modified locally.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dSgjl6PDpsj

A rounded square wall generator. Takes only 4 values:

Size
Height
Thickness
Roundness

I designed this to create thin wall models for calibrating 3d printer nozzle flow rates. The edges are rounded off, which introduces the only limitation in the system: you must have walls at least twice as long as the rounding, if you'd like to understand better why, feel free to read the "thin wall.scad" and/or the Minkowski documentation: https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Transformations#minkowski

There are lots of good calibration guides, like this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52946

Unfortunately the only thin wall model I could find caused weird print errors, an STL error perhaps.

Rather than keep hunting for a STL, I thought I'd make this generator, so anyone could make their own calibration model.

I will be making a TouchDRO case that will accept 3 USB ports for my mill soon. I've included .step, .sldprt (solidworks), and .stl for any editing you wish to do. Thanks enjoy.

description.text:
To note: weekday tags on the sliding lids are in English!

In this pill-box, you can organize and store a full week of therapy, with up to 5 daily slots of your pills (say: morning, lunchtime, dinner, bedtime, plus one spare for each weekday).

Using this pill box, you don't risk to mix up your medicines, especially when you have complex therapies, with multiple pills to take at specific times of the day.

For instance, you can prepare your entire weekly therapy on a Saturday night, then start taking your pills next Sunday morning, and so on for the whole week. You just need to slide open each day's lid from the top/right, so to dump out only those pills that you need to take at that specific time/day.

Each compartment is big enough to store many pills, up to 10, depending on the size. Well enough for the most patients.

SIZE of the assembled box, with sliding lids:
L 195 mm x D 140 mm x H 30 mm (L 7"11/16 x D 5"1/2 x H 1"3/16)

This project has been inspired by LoboCNC's One Month Pill Box (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758586), although it has been totally redesigned.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PRINTING TIME
With these settings it took me:

  • roughly 17 hors to print the main body of the box
  • roughly 6 hors to print the array of seven sliding lids (with weekday name tags)

As I said, this project has been inspired by LoboCNC's One Month Pill Box (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758586), although it has been totally redesigned.

I did it on OnShape.
It's called "One Week Pill Box" by DanRom624.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/22169497262d846baa79d42c/w/b6862610378a025aa37ec76f/e/ea46441133b3aad9127e309d

title: Hot Tub Spa Cover Lifter Holder Support Bracket

description.text:
A better way to support your Hottub Spa cover. I was tired of the lifter support arm stretching and tearing the middle seam of my hottub covers. This ruins the cover and increases the gap allowing heat to escape.

  1. The arm of a typical spa hottub cover lifter should not be positioned in the middle where the cover folds. This creates unnecessary torque and stretches and damages the cover. The arm should be adjusted shorter to be approx 1/4-1/3 distance offset from the center as shown in picture. For my cover I had to cut the arm with a hacksaw and drill new holes for the self tapping screws in order to re position my cross bar 1/4 offset from center.
  2. Print 4 bracket pieces and glue 2 back to back to make 1 bracket.
  3. Purchase 2 simple straps from the dollar store and loop through bracket and around hottub lift bar. Adjust accordingly. My bracket slipped in nicely to the lift handles to remain secure but these brackets can simply rest in place anywhere on the edge of the cover.
  4. Pictures are self explanatory.

author: Motoarzan

description.text:
Aesthetically pleasing rounded case for the Sonoff Basic WiFi Smart Switch.

The white molded plastic enclosure for the Sonoff WiFi switch is functional, but not very pretty. This becomes particularly obvious when you are using the switch to control something fancy, like a decorative lamp. The Sonoff switch also has a bright green LED on it, which is useful for pairing, but can become a nuisance at night when you are trying to sleep.

The oval button on top of this case transfers force down to the small black button on the Sonoff switch. So it is possible to turn appliances on and off while the switch is in its enclosure. The tail end of the oval button should be glued to the inside of the lid as shown.

I have found that by printing with wood-infused filament, and then applying a wood stain, I can get a pretty good wood-like finish on the box. I print the button out of black ABS and sand down the top to make it smooth.

I've included the OpenSCAD source, so this case could potentially be customized for larger or smaller switches.

Car Phone holder.
I printed this for my Zafira, hence the tilted bottom.
It is designed to hold a phone with the case still attached.
I have included the 123dx file so you can edit it to your own needs.

A fan mount for a simple, quick and easy soldering fume extractor. Fits most 120mm case fans and a roughly 10mm thick active carbon filter. Just sandwich the filter between the frame and the fan, snap on the feet, and you're done.

I made some stencils to line up comic frames on an A5 page size.
Though since I'm in 'murica, I only have inch based paper. You can scale down to say 80% to fit on a small sketch pad.

If you want to draw a frame that takes up multiple in size, just don't draw the lines in between. When you remove the stencil, connect up the edges.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50

Notes:

This was designed in fusion 360, you may need to rotate it -90 deg in your slicer.
The flat (not curved) side should be against the print bed.

Create a 2 point rectangle for the "page", decide the cell count, do some math so you have around 4mm between each cell in all directions. Create a rectangle for the "cell" with that cell size 4 mm (at the least) from the edges. Use a rectangular pattern to replicate the "cell" across the "page" with a distance of around 4mm between each "cell".

From a horizontal view, select the top edges and fillet them by 1mm. This will add some tolerance to your pencil or pen swinging around to trace the frames.

Hello and congratulations on finding my drawer while browsing through the vast thingiverse. This here is a nice desk drawer I designed. I can hold 3 shelves at a time, and there are multiple drawer configurations. I personally designed this shelf from the ground up, and it is my first thing ever. Also, it is fully printable WITHOUT supports, provided that all the parts are rotated as shown in the images above. For more information, please go to my website (url below). If you have any desired layout or modules for the shelf, please leave it in in the comments. If you like the design, please feel free to leave me a tip to help me save up to get a 3D printer!

Instructions

When finished printing, sand down any blemishes on the outside of the drawers, and the inside of the main shelf unit. After that, simply slide the drawers into the main compartment. The drawers should fit snugly, with rails to support them.

The Inspiration

This drawer here was designed by me one weekend when I wanted to find a good desk drawer. After finding them, I quickly discovered that they took hours on end to print. It was then that I decided that I wanted to design a efficent, good looking, and modular drawer that printed within two hours or so. So I went to work, and came up with this drawer here.

Contact Me

If you need more information, please go to my website at https://sites.google.com/view/seanshekhman, or leave a question in the comments below.

title: Side-Mount (V.1.8 & 1.9) with Spool-Holder for ANYCUBIC I3 MEGA

description.text:
Hier handelt es sich um eine Co-Produktion von MaikMechanical (Ma Zy), der den Spulenhalter konstruiert hat und mir, der den Side-Mount für den Extruder konstruiert hat.
Durch die seitliche Anbringung des Extruders mit dem darunter liegenden Spulenhalters hat das Filament von der Spule bis zum Extruder einen extrem kurzen und vor allem geraden Weg ohne großartige Kurven oder Knigge in Kauf nehmen zu müssen. Außerdem ist damit etwas an Platz gewonnen!
Die einzelnen Bauteile können natürlich auch einzeln verwendet werden, man braucht nicht zwingend für das eine das andere Teil! In Kombination finde ich persönlich beide aber gar nicht schlecht!

Für diejenigen, bei denen es mit der Bemessung, sprich dem Abstand zum Kasten des X-Achse, zu knapp ist, ist nun die Version 1.9 vorhanden!

Printer:

ANYCUBIC I3 MEGA

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

min. 50 %

Notes:

Der Support wird lediglich für die zwei kleinen "Schnappnasen" am Side-Mount benötigt und kann leicht mit einem Messer oder einer kleinen Feile entfernt werden. Ansonsten wird KEIN Support benötigt!

Für die Befestigung des Extruders am side-mount werden zwei M4 Schrauben mit Mutter benötigt!
Eine der Schrauben muss mind. M4x10 sein und die andere mind. M4x12 (für die Mitanbringung des Sensorhalters)!

Zu den Spulenhalter (spool-holder):

Es gibt zwei Varianten:

Variante 1 (ästhetisch): mit Senkung und Senkschraube

Variante 2 (schnell): mit M8-Schraube aus dem Keller ;-)

zusätzlich benötigte Komponenten:

Variante 1:
Senkschraube min. M8x35 (z.B. DIN 7991)
Sechskantmutter M8 (z.B. DIN 934)
erhältlich in jedem Baumarkt.

Variante 2:
Sechskant- oder Inbusschraube min. M8x35 oder ähnliches
Sechskantmutter M8

Bei den Spulenrohren (coil-tubes) sind drei für unterschiedliche Spulenbreiten zur Auswahl:
75 mm

title: mini E3D V6 x-carriage for linear rails (Renkforce RF500)

description.text:
This mini x-carriage is tailored as a replacement kit for swapping out the original V3 extruder with a standard E3D V6 or V6 clone on a Renkforce RF500 - but can also be used to be attached on any standard linear rail.

As a positive side-effect, it will increase the Z-axis to 200mm - which means, you have to unmount or rebuild the Z-endstop or the hotend will not be able to reach the print bed.
After replacement you will be able to tweak the maximum print area to 220x150x200.

Depending on the parts you want to (re-)use you have to print the following things:
1) "e3d mount main part" - always needed
2) "e3d mount clamp" - choose either with or without integraded fan mount
3) "cable mgmt" - this thing can be used to tie the cables to the carriage. I personally prefer to stick a piece of stiff wire into the hole and fasten the cables to there with a zip-tie...
4) "e3d sensor mount " - you have to use the sn04 type of sensor because a standard inductive sensor will be too big for the RF500 (For the sake of completeness a standard sensor mount is added to the collection).
5) "e3d fan mount" - choose the one which fits your fan. the standard part cooling fan on the RF500 is a 25mm fan.

You will need some M3 (for the endstop M2) screws and nuts:
1) 6 x M3x16 and 2 x M3 nuts, 2 x M2x12 and 4 x M2 nuts
2) 2 x M3x16 and 2 x M3 nuts, 4 x M3x14 for the hotend fan
3) 2 x M3x12, 2 x M3x20 and 2 x M3 nuts
4) 2 x M3x12 and either 4 x M2x14 for the 25mm fan or 4 x M3x14 for the 30mm fan

author: Andraxis

description.text: Retainer Roof Clips Volkswagen Caravelle

The vise consists only from 3 different 3D printed parts and 2 M6 threaded rods with 6 nuts – it is very easy to make one. Four of the six nuts have additionally printed knobs that tightly fit on them. The vise has V-shaped grooves compatible with PCB,s up to 2.5 mm thick. PCB can be mounted in 4 planes (tilted, vertical, horizontal). In addition, there are holes for cylindrical neodymium magnets 10 x 4 mm at the bottom – also for “press-fit”. This vise was designed in that way to be relatively easy to print on a 3D printer. It is quite small – only 75 mm in width and 32 mm in height so it doesn’t take much valuable space in your workshop.

You need to print:
1x PCBholder-_jaw.stl
1x PCBholder-_jaw_base.stl
4x PCBholder-_thumb_screw.stl

Recommended printing settings:
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Printing speed: 40-60 mm/s
Filament: ABS/ASA
Infill: Honeycomb 30% or more
Outlines: 2 or more
Top/Bottom 100% layers: 3 or more
Support: Yes - Inside the nut pockets
Nozzle: 0.4 mm

Description of this project on my web page:
http://bytechlab.pl/en/2018/02/very-simple-pcb-vise/

title: BeagleBone Black and Replicape Box

description.text:
This box for BeagleBone Black and Replicape is a bit taller to accommodate an extra stacking header between the BBB and the Replicape.

Unique(?) features include:

  • Mount point for a 50mm blower, aimed to blow air between the BBB and Replicape to cool off any installed heat sinks for the stepper drivers. The mount was lifted from the extruder mount for the Hypercube Evolution.
  • Cut-out to allow a MicroSD extender to exit the case
  • Cut-out to allow a 90 degree USB host extender to exit the case
  • Mounting holes for the BeagleBone are sized for threaded brass inserts to be glued into place.

This is still a work in progress, though I do hope I'm nearly finished.

The V2 file incorporates a mount location for an USB panel-mount receptacle instead of the huge slot. Digi-Key part #MUSB-A511-00-ND.

title: Tevo Tarantula Z-axis pillow block supports
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These are left and right pillow block supports for the Tevo Tarantula. When installed the pillow block(s) help remove the Z-axis movement allowed by the flex coupling between the top mounted stepper motor(s) and linear Z-axis screw(s)

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25

Notes:

There are 2 different support blocks, (left & right) designed for Tevo Tarantula printers with two Z-axis lead screws and top mounted stepper motors.

The alternate right block allows the stepper motor and lead screw to remain at the full right hand side of the printer.

Print them upside down without supports.

If you are printing on glass this will put the smooth surface at the top once installed on the printer.

Parts List Installation Notes

PARTS:
2 x M4-12mm hex socket screw
2 x M4-16mm hex socket screw
4 x 4mm washers
2 x 4mm nuts
2 x M4 T-Nut

INSTALLATION:
Loosen the bracket holding the 8mm lead screw nut to the X-axis 20x40 extrusion. You may have to lower the Z-axis manually until the plate with the attached lead screw nut is free.
Insert two of the M4-12mm hex socket screws with 4mm washers through the 2 holes in the support, add the two M4 T-Nuts in preparation for installing in the bottom extrusion..
Slide the 8mm lead screw through the large hole in the support and align the T-nuts in the printers bottom 20x40 extrusion, then tighten in place.
Check alignment at this point and adjust the position of the stepper motor bracket or pillow block support as necessary.
Let the pillow block slide down to the support and fasten it to the support with the remaining hardware.
Put about 0.5-1.0mm of upward pressure on the flex coupling, raising the 8mm lead screw just a little, and tighten the set screws of the pillow block.
Raise the Z-axis and reattach the bracket holding the 8mm lead screw nut to the X-axis 20x40 extrusion.
Raise the Z-axis up to it's upper limit and check the alignment. You may have to loosen the screws holding the Z-axis stepper motors and/or the bracket holding the 8mm lead screw nut to the X-axis to make sure each assembly is properly aligned.

Repeat for the other side.

If you only have one Z-axis stepper motor and lead screw, print the one for the side you installed Z-axis stepper motor on. You will only need half the parts listed.

For further Z-axis accuracy replace the 8mm lead screw nut(s) with anti backlash nut(s) at the same time.

Edit Text

author: Justy_guy

description.text:
Fate Stay Night VN, the most powerfull sword
2 meters long
Rendering 360 Autodesk

Update 3/3/2018
This is an update to post my V2 of this awesome project. I have changed some purchased components to make this flashlight more reliable, but I haven't yet received my new LED's, yet so the testing results are still TBD.

This Build is slightly more expensive, but the good news is I have made it mostly able to be disassembled, you still need to epoxy the board and solder all connections but other than that, it comes apart! very cool.

other features updated: Adjustable beam angle, Recharge indicator viewing hole, more than 200% the heat sink thermal mass and surface area, smaller button, flex grip handle and lanyard, easier wiring and assembly.

Updated Purchased Parts:
The only three changes to the below Bill of Materials are the LED, LED Driver Board and more copper heat sinks. I chose Cree's most efficient LED line, the XP-E2 r4 mounted to a Noctigon 16mm copper MCPCB (https://intl-outdoor.com/noctigon-xp16-mcpcb-cree-xpe2-r4-1a-led-p-772.html) These LED's are rated for 1A but after research I found that they can be overclocked by 300% safely (just a lot of heat to get rid of) so I chose to run 1.4A boards with 3 or 5 modes. (https://www.fasttech.com/p/1122401) these will also serve as your lights under voltage protection device. Lastly you need these large copper heat sinks as well as the smaller ones listed below. (https://www.amazon.com/Enzotech-Graphics-Passive-Copper-8-pack/dp/B002BWXW6E/ref=sr_1_2?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1520097988&sr=1-2&keywords=14mm+copper+heatsink)

Updated printed parts
To be safe please redownload all files and delete your old ones. Small changes were made to V1 parts. In order to print this V2 you must be able to print flexible materials!! The lens is held by the hex cover to make it an adjustable beam.
Two heat sinks must be soldered together as shown in the renderings and the heat sink soldered directly to the MCPCB if your using aluminum you have to use the thermal adhesive pads that come with the sinks.
I have left the V1 STLs up so be careful to choose the right files to print.
No need to glue the button down, it is held in place by the soldered wires
No need to glue the heat sinks in, they are held in by the wires, epoxy if you want to.

End Update 3/3/2018

Here is the Version 1 of my Flashlight design. This is a slightly advanced maker project due to the tight soldering and various printing materials. You must be able to print ABS at the very least, NinjaFlex if you want to use the soft button and hex lens cover.

This project is worthwhile if you want to make many flashlights as gifts and such because many of the components are sold in packs of 10 for cost effectiveness.

Caution! The way that these components work together, the highest setting will Burn out the LED at Full Battery Charge!!! I use the lowest setting mostly and even then the heat sink gets pretty hot after a while.

Warning! the Copper heat sink is exposed for cooling purposes and can become very hot. yes I have slightly burned my self sticking my pinky finger in the hole to see how hot it was. It's hot!

List of Purchased Components

  • 18mm Acrylic Convex Lens (2 packs/ $0.51ea) https://www.fasttech.com/p/4539801
  • 16mm LED Driver (10packs/ $1.15ea) https://www.ebay.com/i/251690022903?chn=ps&fl=a
  • 16mm Cree XM-L LED T6 White (1, 5, 10 packs/ $1.88ea) https://www.ebay.ca/itm/10W-Cree-Single-Die-XM-L-LED-T6-White-1040Lm-3000mA-led-chip-16mm-20mm-pcb-F-DIY-/322153245872
  • Micro USB TP4056 18650 Lithium Battery Charger Module (5 packs, $1.40ea) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XQRQR3Q/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • 18650 Lithium Cell - I have a bunch so I dont have a specific link (~$2.00/ea)
  • Self Locking Micro Switch (6 packs/ $0.75ea) https://www.ebay.ca/itm/6-Pieces-Black-Latching-self-locking-1A-push-button-on-off-micro-mini-1208-YD-B5/252946680354?hash=item3ae4cc0a22:g:s14AAOSwfpVZHsGH
  • Mosfet Passive Heat Sink 10x10x14mm, Copper (10packs/ $2.00ea) https://www.amazon.com/Enzotech-Mosfet-Passive-Copper-10-pack/dp/B004CL89D8/ref=sr_1_1?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1518994641&sr=1-1&keywords=Enzotech+Mosfet+Passive+Heat+Sink%2C+10+x+10+x+14+mm%2C+Copper

Total cost of one Flashlight = ~$10.00 + Printed Parts + You're invaluable Time.

  • Print All core pieces out of ABS or your preferred high strength high temp resistant material. -Print all pieces standing on end with a 0.4mm nozzle @0.2mm/lyr (recommended large brim)
  • Print the Shell in any material you want, vertically with charger hole down
    -Support everything to 55-60° overhang @ 20% zigzag
  • I print ninjaflex at 240°C and 8mm/sec speed everywhere. (you have to run a lot of material thru before you push out the last of what ever was in the nozzle before. Just keep trying)

Assembly
1) Solder a very short lead from the out(-) on the charger module directly to the negative side of the 18650 Cell. Make sure not to install the board too close to the battery, it could short if done wrong. I added a drop of epoxy once assembled to keep the board separated from the battery.
2) Solder a longer lead from the out(+) on the charger module directly to the positive end of the 18650 Cell. This lead should be just long enough to reach, so cut it to length and strip. the wire has to fit in the groove of the battery holder piece so make sure all support or print bumps are eliminated in this groove.
3) Solder a 5 inch lead to the same place as the out(-) on the negative side of the battery. This lead also has to fit into the groove on the battery holder so use thin wires. I used 24 AWG solid for these wires. this wire will go to one side of the switch, doesn't matter witch side.
4) Solder a short flexible length of wire to the same place on the positive battery terminal. place the battery and charger into the battery holder piece. as you slide the battery into place, guide the negative wire out the bottom and the positive wire through the end
5) Epoxy Charge board to the battery holder such that the charger port is flush with the end of the flat plate. Use the same batch of epoxy to ensure the board stays separated from the battery. Clamp lightly in place while adhesive cures. Glue the battery in place if you want to as well. I didn't.
6) Solder the positive wire that is sticking out of the end of the battery holder part to the center plate on the back side of the LED Driver module. Make sure that the LED Driver is totally round by trimming it with a rotary tool. I will not fit otherwise.
7) Solder a 2 inch lead to the outside ring on the back of the LED Driver. This wire will also go to the switch and will be trimmed to length when soldering in the switch.
8) Push the LED Driver into the end of the Battery Holder making sure not to break the connections you've made. The LED Driver Board should be flush with the rim of the end.
9) De-solder the leads from the LED Driver making note witch side was positive and negative. Bend the tips of the leads and hook them thru the notches on the CREE LED and solder them to the LED.
10) Using the provided adhesive patches that came with the Copper Heat Sinks, attach the sink as square and center as possible on the back of the led. this is important to make sure the led is straight, use the break lines on the top and bottom as alignment tools. you can place and replace if your careful. then press it on hard when you've got a good position. Don't bend the copper pin fins.
11)make sure that the Sink fits into the LED Holder part and the leads are only sticking out a short amount before gluing it in place. I epoxied the inside of the four support pillars to the corner pins. Press the assembled LED and Sink into place
12) epoxy the lens into the LED holder, there is a step that will not let it go too far. make sure the Lens is clean to your liking, it will not be removable. nothing is really.
13) Test the polarity of the LED and LED Driver by touching the switch wires together and carefully setting the two leads of the led to where the wires were originally soldered. if no light, try the reverse polarity. once it flashes make note of the polarity.
14) making sure the switch leads are not touching, solder the LED leads to the LED driver. Twist the wires slightly so that the LED Holder and Battery Holder come together (don't glue yet). you can continue testing the connections by touching the switch wires together.
15) making sure that the locking button is depressed (off) epoxy it into place and solder the switch leads to it, polarity doesn't matter for mechanical switches. Continue testing the light but don't leave it on for more than a short moment.
16) Make sure that the Shell part is clear of debris inside. Test fitting before electrical assembly is recommended.
17) Epoxy the LED Holder part to the Battery holder part and quickly insert the entire core assembly into the Shell part and press it all into place. the switch button should appear centered in the button hole.
18) Epoxy edge of bottom of flexible button to the flat spots exposed to the button hole.

Now you've got a homemade 3d printed LED Flashlight!

I cant stress enough not to use the high setting for more than .25 seconds. the light will turn bluish and you WILL burn out the LED. This Flashlight was not meant to be taken apart for repair, unless you can manage to assemble it that way.

I look forward to seeing your makes! That is if you get this made successfully. please let me know in the comments what you think and how it could be improved. I will be working on a bike light that uses an external portable battery pack.

Good Luck and Happy Printing!

I loved the Druidic Dice Tower but I wanted it to have a dice tray, so now it does! As with the original, print at 110% for larger dice (though see Version 5.2 below).

About Version 2:
After uploading, I noticed the original was very slightly off center looking to me, so I moved the dice tray a tiny bit and now I think it looks slightly better. I uploaded this slightly more centered version and labeled it helpfully "2."

About Version 3:
I wanted to find something that would be a bit less smooth and ordered than the dice tray I had used, so I went searching and found a fire ring that looked like it would do the trick (see remix sources). Version 3 is my favorite so far.

About Version 5.2:
I printed Version 3 and it turned out awesome! The only hitch is that it didn't work with d20s! After some analysis and quick work with a dremel, d20s now fit in my printed Version 3, however I thought I could do better than simply advising everyone start hacking away at their towers, so I made some hopefully not too crude smoothing adjustments to the interior of the stone archway that should help larger dice like d20s and d12s go through. I also roughed-up the path leading out of the stone archway a little bit. I plan on printing this in the next week or two, but if you beat me to it please let me know how well it works with your larger dice.

About Version 5.Smoothed: Ok, I kind of went nuts with the smoothing brush all over the inner surfaces of the dice tower :3 (otherwise equivalent to Version 5.2)

comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
Really cool! I am printing the set for my daughter at 1.75 scale. Really looking forward to the next animal!
Not super happy with the attachment method. I think if the attachment cylinders had more contact area, you could lightly sand them to achieve the fit you want. The way this current model connects only has a very small contact area and that doesn't leave you much room for adjustment.
Especially if you used that surface as the base when you printed. Now you have even less contact area because you have to sand a small amount off to correct the smooshed out effect you get with the first layer. Maybe the fit is a little tighter with ABS shrink but for PLA, they are a little loose for a toy.
Still love the idea and can't wait for more. I will post pics of the larger version of these!
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
thanks for your feedback. I've tested the assembly only with ABS. It works pretty well. I will try to make a better attachment method following your advice, but I also want to avoid manual finishing like sandind if possible.
Did you try the eggO assembly ? the attachment design of the parts is similar but a bit different.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
I didn't try the egg chair yet. I am having a couple issues with the models fitting together well on the original animal but being loose on some of the others and I print them all at the same orientation.
I really do think if you made the slightest interference and the contact surface the complete cylinder, it would give a more forgiving assembly. With this style, I go from not possible to assemble because of the smooshed first layer, to VERY SLIGHTLY sanding with 1000 grit paper and they are now too loose and fall out.
It could be PLA but that is the direction MBI is going, look at their 5th gens, none of them have a heated bed!
I am almost done with the 3rd set at 1.75 scale. I will upload pics soon!!
comments.author: mageli

comments.text:
Mageli, I had another idea (I know, I am full of them). Could you put a coarse thread on them? It wouldn't require more than 1 thread to lock them together. Kind of like the thread on the sample MakerBolt from MakerWare. I don't think you would need more than one and it would have to line up properly with each section. May not work, just thought I would put it out there.
Moving on to the Shark now!!
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
Thanks for your idea. You're right, a thread could be a good way to avoid any problem using various materials with different properties for same 3D model. I've chosen to attach the part with a clip system or a tight adjustment to allow the parts to turn freely relatively to the others for a better playing experiment (it's important to be able to turn the head for instance !). It may be also easier for young children to clip rather than screw the parts together.
I will try to enhance the attachment system for better gameplay and easier printing.

author: moze13

title: Oscillating Steam (Air) Engine - 1941 Popular Mechanics Magazine

description.text:
In April of 1941 Popular Science Magazine had an article on how to build an oscillating steam engine. This model is a reproduction of that engine using the part details in the article. I tried to stay true to the parts in almost all aspects. Some things were altered to allow 3D printing.

This model has a reversing lever that redirects the air flow to enable CW and CCW rotation.

While originally designed out of metal for use with steam, this engine runs on compressed air. Please don't try steam. It is a very leaky design.

This engine is running around 1500-1600 RPM.

Build Details:

  1. While the Assembly list calls out 8 mm screws. 6 mm should work in most places, especially the cylinder heads. Item 3 12 mm screw can be shorter.
  2. Spring is 23/64 Dia x 1 3/8 Long
  3. IMPORTANT: Make sure you assemble the lower cylinder cover (12) to the Piston before assembling the piston crank. Attach with Super Glue.
  4. Assemble the Rocker Shaft (20) to the Cylinder(6) with Super Glue.
  5. The mating surfaces of the Cylinder(6), Reverser Plate(19) and Frame(9) need to be smooth.
  6. Parts 4 and 5 have been combined.

Please let me know if you need more details or find any issues.

Enjoy

UPDATE: Added .step file of the assembly - 18 FEB 18

Video of engine in motion
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K9ak1Hcorfg
Video of engine in slow motion.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iP8OPRIgomE

Link to Original Article
https://books.google.com/books?id=iycDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&dq=april+1941+popular+science&pg=PA188&hl=en#v=twopage&q&f=false

http://www.jefferyjensen.com/dw/engineer-mechanical/steamengines - About 1/2 way down the page.

Notes:

Baseline settings for Simplify3d used for Anet A8 with E3D V6 Hotend:

  • 3 layers Top, Bottom, Shell
  • 5mm Extra Inflation Distance (IMPORTANT!)

  • 70% Bridging Extrusion Multiplier
  • CHECK Fixed bridging angle and set to 90deg (IMPORTANT!)
  • CHECK Apply bridging settings to perimeters

I needed a clamp to reach deep inside my RC aircraft frame and this worked.
It is based on a 3/16 square brass tube (K & S #8153) and a 6-32 threaded rod. Both of these come in 12 inch lengths. I cut them in half to make a pair of 6 inch clamps (max jaw opening is about 4 inches). You can make them any length up to 12 inches giving a max jaw opening of 10 inches.
You will also need three 6-32 hex nuts, a 6-32 lock nut and washer that just fits over the threaded rod. Two sets of M-2 x 8mm cap head screw with nut will also be needed.
I found all the parts at my local Ace Hardware. You can also get the sq brass tube and threaded rod from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/PRECISION-METALS-8153-Brass-Tube/dp/B00FZS29WO/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1518902551&sr=8-1&keywords=k%26s+8153&dpID=31r5dGRh1XL&preST=_SX300_QL70_&dpSrc=srch
https://www.amazon.com/Small-Parts-56055-Threaded-6-32/dp/B0719J9K4D/ref=sr_1_7?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1518902635&sr=1-7&keywords=6-32+rod&dpID=319dtX0PqhL&preST=_SX342_QL70_&dpSrc=srch

To assemble:
Put a nut on the threaded rod about 1 3/4 inches from the end. Slide the handle onto the rod up against the nut. This will leave about 1/4 inch of threaded rod sticking out the back side of the handle. Put another nut on the protruding rod and pull the rod with nut into the back of the handle then tighten the first nut with a wrench or pliers.
Slide the rod into the handle support piece and run a nut down the rod until it fits into the hex socket. Slide the handle support onto one end of the brass tube and lock in place with the M-2 nut and bolt. Do not overtighten, the M2 nut and bolt just needs to be snug.
Slide the movable jaw onto the sq brass tube with the jaw facing away from the handle. There is a socket that the 6-32 rod fits into. You then place the lock-nut and washer in the cutout on the movable jaw and thread the rod just enough that it holds the lock-nut and washer from falling out. See the picture.
Finally slide the fixed jaw onto the sq brass tube and lock in place with the other M-2 nut and bolt.
This design makes a useful clamp that is surprisingly strong. To expand on its' utility a variety jaws could be printed to perform many functions. A notch 10mm wide should just fit over the basic jaws presented here. I envision wider jaws, taller jaws, curved jaws, serrated jaws and so on.
Printed in PLA with 50% fill

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Spool Holder, Single Side ClipOn

title: Versatile Spool Holder for Prusa MK2/3 (and not only)

description.text:
This is versatile spool holder for Prusa I3 MK2/2S/3 frame and not only. I am using the Area51's clever ClipOn design. There is also a version for aluminum extrusion frames . Unfortunately I do not have aluminum extrusions to try it , so if someone makes it, please give feedback.

You can use smooth rods or threaded rods of 8mm,10mm,12mm diameter (one version for each diameter). With smooths rods you can use something like alexrosa's 3D Print Spool Holder Filament Support or boksbox's hub adapter. If you prefer a hub with bearings you can print a design like butchja's Universal Filament Spool Holder and mount it on threaded rod. You can use it as single filament holder or double filament holder (see photos and renders).
I also included a clip (one for each diameter) for smooth rods.

Acknowledgements
Thanks to:
Area51 for the ClipOn Design.
alexrosa for the 3D Print Spool Holder Filament Support
butchja for the Universal Filament Spool Holder
boksbox for the Hub Adapter

remixed_from.title: ANET A8 | V2 Rear Bed Level Sensor Holder - Customizable

description.text:
Improved rear bed level sensor holder for Anet A8. Designed for tapped holes for secure mounting.

Requirements

  • M3x0.5 cap screws. 8mm long.
  • M3x0.5 bottoming tap.
  • M4x0.7 metric round head screws. 5mm long.
  • M4x0.7 plug tap.

Assembly

  1. !! IMPORTANT !! -- Tapping the bearing blocks

    DO NOT TAP FROM THE WRONG SIDE!!

    Tapping from the WRONG SIDE will result in cross threading the existing holes! This would make the bearing blocks not secure for hotend mounting!

    Tap M4x0.7 from the FRONT using the existing threads and tap THROUGH the bearing blocks all the way through to the back. See attached image.

  2. Tap the four clip mount holes with the M3x0.5. Be careful not to tap too deep and split (or strip) the part. If this happens, print another part and try again.

  3. The rest of the assembly should be straight forward and self explanatory.

Firmware configuration

Due to the altered sensor position the following changes have to be done in the configuration.h file.

For E3Dv6 mount / carriage:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 51

With the stock carriage:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 26
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 51

Additionally for all setups:

#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 51

title: Desktop Smart Phone and Tablet Holder

description.text:
My family keeps crowding my desk with phones, tablets, and kindles to be charged via USB - I needed a place to hold them out of the way while they do their thing.  
Created in OpenSCAD with detail level set high and using inches for measurement.

This is a work in progress.  I'm still doing my first few test prints.
I suspect that for holding small devices it will print out easily enough on the makerbot replicator when positioned normally.  One will just need to resize and place flat.
However, to ensure that tablets can fit -- we'll need to build on its side.  I tried to design so that it will not fall over, but we may need to enable support or something else to get this OK at the largest scale.

author: MattM

description.text: 4 rows

Hi guys.

This is my FLEX MOUNT DESIGN that I build for my Hypercube.

Features:

ONE MOUNTING PLATE FOR ALL DESIGNS, FEATURING:
  • Integrated Belt Tensioner
  • Insert Pockets for all M3 Nuts
  • Easy accessible 4 Hole Mounting Points for the different Extruder Plates
  • Can be mounted on the standard Tech2c bushing holders
  • Files:
    • Mounting Plate: druckkopftraeger_2
    • Bottom Slider of Belt Tensioner: schieber
    • Clamping Plate for Belt Tensioner: schieber_klemmplatte
STANDARD DESIGN E3D BOWDEN MOUNT:
  • Insert Pockets for all M3 Nuts
  • Zip-Tie holes for better fixing of the flexible cable tubing
  • Mounting Positions for Tech2cs Fan Nozzle, Radial Fan, Sensor Mount are identical
  • Files:
    • E3D V6 Mounting Plate: e3d_traeger_bowden
    • Mounting Bracket for BlTouch: bltouch_mount_bracket
E3D TITAN DIRECT DRIVE MOUNT:
  • Titan-Direct-Extruder-Design
  • Large cooling fan nozzle for minimum air flow resistance
  • Mount for Bltouch
  • Zip-Tie holes for better fixing of the flexible cable tubing
  • Files:
    • E3D Titan Direct Drive Mounting Plate: e3d_traeger
    • Mounting Bracket for BlTouch: bltouch_mount_bracket
    • Mounting Plate for cooling fan: mounting_plate_fan
    • Mooling Nozzle: cooling_nozzle (This part needs to be printed with support "Touching Buildplate")

Nema 17 Pancake Stepper: 17HS08-1004S | Aliexpress Link

All Parts are easy to print. Except for the cooling nozzle you do not need any support structure. I printed all of the parts with a layer height of 0,2mm and a 0,4mm nozzle.
Please feel free to remix my design and also add different sensor mounts if you like.

You can find the Assy as a Step-File in the downloads.

I CANNOT guarantee that my direct extruder design will fit on all hypercubes without any build size reduction. I tried to keep the whole assembly as compact as possible. Nonetheless I had to move the extrusion profile on the top front down (as you can see on my pictures) because my extruder was hitting it. I am also still using my external motor mounts which allow me to use the same build size as before.

comments.text: Heya Markus, I have some doubts on the belt tensioner here.
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Hi Jamie, there is no threaded hole in the "schieber" part. The two tensioning screws are turning freely inside of the holes. And they must turn freely otherwise this part would not move at all. I started my design with something similar to the part that you have posted and I also tried it on my previous carriage. But I did not like it, it wasn't rigid enough for me and it bend because of the belts pulling force. You are right that with my belt tensionier you can only tension both belts at the same time. I tried to split the moving parts but it wasn't rigid enough. I was a little unhappy that I could not split it but after I mounted it to my Hypercube the doubts where gone. I first adjusted it roughly pulling one belt than the other and than looked if my x-slider is rectangular to the y-axis. It took me about 2 minutes and than i locked the screws fully on the schieber part.
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Ah of course, the screws push the tensioner block outwards. I see it now. I'm an idiot :) Thanks for clarifying!

description.text:
A dice tower and/or dice box. The dice box is collapsible and becomes a case for dice. The dice tower can also fit inside the dice box case.

DiceBoxCase: A dice box that you roll your dice into so they don't roll off the table.
DiceBoxClasp: A clasp that holds the DiceBoxCase closed.
DiceTower: Put your dice into the hole at the top and your dice will exit at the bottom. The DiceTower will fit inside the DiceBoxCase.

The pictures show 9 dice being contained within the dice tower as the dice tower itself is contained within the dice box. To store the dice in the dice tower, hold it in your hand while blocking the exit, then place the dice in the top hole, largest first. You might be able to fit more depending on the size of your dice and the thickness of the felt you use (if any). If, like me, you have loads of dice, then consider printing more dice boxes to store them all.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ppz4e1AyIYA

description.text:
This is a personal project to design a bait box I can use when I take worms out of my garden to go fishing. Holes in the top are to allow air to circulate keeping bait from going off. A filter insert is designed to allow the soil to pass through to the lid, leaving worms exposed and easier to grab. I have yet to try out this design, so I included 3 ideas for the filter. Scale needs to be adjusted and design tested out. The box itself should be fitted so it stays together with friction. If it doesn't I may consider either adding strap loops around the outside (with the benefit of being able to secure it to a fishing pack with a carabiner) or redesigning the lid to allow the base to snap into place.

If you make one, please send in pictures and let me know what worked or what didn't. I'm working on putting

title: Indicator holder for 0XA toolpost
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't have the smaller Shars dial indicator or AXA tool post that the original was designed for. I do have a 2" Harbor Freight dial indicator and an 0XA tool post on my mini-lathe. And so a remix was in order.

Because of the longer body and stem of the 2" dial indicator and the shorter width of the 0XA tool holders, I flipped the cutout for the dial so it was at the back of the holder instead of the front. I also added an M6 thread for the offset nuts, and made two types of M6 knurled cap nuts for it. One is flat, the other domed to make it easier to use one to lock down on the other.

I included mirrored versions of the holder, one for coming in from the side, one for coming in from the front. One interesting note - when working with Fusion360, when you mirror a part that contains threads, the threads flip orientation as well. I printed a couple of left hand threaded pieces before I realized what was going on and fixed it.

I made an M6 knurled bolt to fasten the indicator in place, but also included a cap that you can super glue to a regular M6 bolt instead.

title: Fan cooler attachment for Windows Mixed Reality Headsets (Lenovo Explorer & Dell Visor)

description.text:
Tired of heat buildup inside your headset? Need some fresh air in your face while exploring virtual worlds? Then try this fan duct for the Lenovo Explorer and Dell Visor WMR Headsets. It might fit other headsets if the measures are similar.

This fan duct will direct a 40mm fan exhaust towards the nose bridge of the wearer and introduce some airflow into the visor, gently cooling your face. The extra flow of fresh air increases comfort for longer play times in warm environments.

You just need to add:
· 1x USB 40mm Fan (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B071JB9WYB/)
· 1x USB Powerbank
· Some velcro straps and double side tape.
· 4 m3x15mm screws or glue to attach the fan to the shroud.

These are the designs currently available.
v0.3 (shorter) - Places the fan closer to your face, does not interfere with the cameras.
v0.3 Dell Experimental Edition - Adds a curvature to the front-facing wall so it may fit slightly rounded WMR Headsets better. I can't try this one myself so feedback is welcome.

The fan duct has been sized to be as low profile and unobtrusive as possible. Therefore it is highly unlikely that it will hit your nose.

I hope you like this design as much as I enjoy using it.

This is a spool holder for ANET Printers A2 & A8. You will need to print the file twice. Each print uses only 14g of filament and takes 60-90 mins depending on your print speed. It will ensure that the spool sits centrally on the 8mm threaded bar. You will either need to mount two spools or use an additional M8 nut to keep the spool holder in place.
If only one spool is used, then a nut must be used to keep the spool holder in place The filament shown here is ICE filament with an internal diameter of 52mm

Dimensions

With the first iteration I had the walls set to 1mm thick. This did work but the spool holders felt too flimsy. For the second attempt I set the wall thickness to 2mm this felt much better.
Very simple but still very customizable drawer for many types of organizers such as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1666929. You can set number of cells and even merge some of them (read further).

Merging rules

You need to define array of merging commands. Each merging command is array of two corner cells (so you are defining array of arrays of array pairs - don't panic, it's simpler than it sounds). All cells in the rectangle defined by corner cells will be merged. Merged cells can be overlaid.

Cell numbering

When you have the drawer oriented with the handle pointing down, the bottom-left corner cell is [0, 0], the bottom-right corner cell is [cells_x-1, 0] and so on.

Example
[
    [             // first merging command
        [0, 1],   // first corner cell
        [2, 2]    // second corner cell
    ],
    [             // second merging command
        [5, 0],   // first corner cell
        [4, 0]    // second corner cell
    ]
]

description.text:
This is a set of 5, 10, and 15mm wire guides that clip into most 20mm aluminum profile extrusion. These have been tested on both random 20mm extrusions and on Openbuilds V-Slot Linear Rail. There is a tight fit on these guides so that they will come loose and they may squeak a little when installing. The 5mm version can also be used as a filament guide. More versions may come soon such as thicker versions, less detailed versions, larger ID holes, etc.

*Note that tolerances will depend on filament type (ABS, PLA, PETG, etc.). These guides were only tested with PETG as of now. Changing the scale factor for the guides can compensate for different filament types.
