This is a design for a pie panel dome hinge to suit Michael Baddeley's V2 R2D2 dome. The hinge is my first 3D design, so I am still learning as I go.

I have included a modified pie panel with a flat spot and screw holes to attach the hinge.

The servo mount is designed for a full sized 40x20x36 servo. I believe it will also work with smaller servos and I may upload versions to suit once I have tested.

Printing

  • There is a split version of the mounting plate included so that it can be printed flat on the cut line with less support material and glued together afterwards.
  • I printed the hinge arm standing up on it's flat pie mounting plate with support material.
  • The pie piece panel can be printed standing up on one of its straight edges, as long as you use a brim to help bed adhesion.

Assembly

  • Glue the mounting plate back together if printed in two parts.
  • Attach the arm to the mounting plate with an m3 screw (>25mm) and nylock nut.
  • Attach the pie piece to the arm with 8mm m3 screws. I tapped the hole a little first with an m3 tap, but not sure this is required.
  • Position the pie piece on the dome and then glue the mounting plate in place where it lands.
  • Adjust pie piece to arm position and glue the connection.
  • My intention is to use a servo linkage with a spring to provide tension on the door while closed.

Warning

This design is still a work in progress. I have printed one test version that seems to work well.
The pie piece is a copy of Mr Baddeley's with a slight chamfer on the bottom edge and a mounting point for the hinge assembly. All other parts have been designed by me using Fusion360.

18/2/2018

I have uploaded another mounting plate designed to suit submicro servos sized around 23x12x23. I have not printed this design yet, or tested if submicro servos have enough torque to open the pie pieces. The servo mounting holes suit m2 screws, or hot glue would probably also work to keep the servo in place.

19/2/2018

v3 versions of the STLs have been uploaded. Changes include:

  • Detail added on inside of pie panel
  • Hinge arm clearances tweaked
  • Micro servo mount screw holes turned into slots.

title: CR-10 RaspberryPi Ethernet Camera Mount Kit

description.text:
I remixed a few other files and borrowed one file with no changes to create this RaspberryPi Mounting kit using a Vilros Raspberry Pi case to mount a Raspberry Pi Camera to a ball joint that plugs into the Ethernet port to position the camera cleaning. This all bolts to the side of the CR-10 control box using the factory screws and places the camera for OctoPrint at a nice angle. I know some prefer to mount directly to the buildplate, but I didn't want to add the mass or deal with cable management. I do need to replace my really long USB cable with a nice compact one to clean up the install a bit more.

Edit added an optional ball mount rotated forward slightly to allow more clearance for 90 degree USB cords.

For better control over the web camera in OctoPrint. Try using "System Command Editor" Plug-in and creating two new menu actions that use:
"sudo service webcamd start" to Turn Camera ON
and
"sudo service webcamd stop" to Turn Camera OFF.

description.text:
This is an PMMA (plexiglas) based enclosure for MPSM mini V1, with a scale of ~40x40x40cm. This will cost less then 50€. I've decide to spare out the filament roll, but its up to you to do same way or include the filament roll into the enclosure.

You need:

  • 3x 40x40cm Plexiglas plates with 3mm thickness
  • 2x 38x40cm Plexiglass plate
    (i bought mine at local store, bought 5x 40x40 and cut off 2 plates by 2cm)
  • 20x M2 8mm screw with nut
    i bet to use only adhesive tape will work too (but minimum for the door you will need 4 screws)
  • adhesive tape
  • cutting machine (dremel or similar)

At first print the uploaded parts:
8x connect_corner
3x connect_corner_bottom
2x connect_door_4_hülse
1x connect_door_3_2
1x connect_door_2
1x connect_door_pin

Then mark on the left plate the area for your power cable, for the spool holder and filament way. cut them out by dremel (be carefull dont cut your fingers by the machine or plexiglas plate). For assembly start with corner bottom parts for rear left/right & front right side, use door_2 for bottom left side. screw or tape 2 or 4 corners to lft, right and back plate. Take upper plate and also scre it to side walls with 4 corners. use remaining door parts and door_pin to screw/ it on the front plate, before screwing adjust the door correctly. Last step should be fix front left/right bottom corner with ur baseplate (in my case i used tape to fix it on the cupboard).

monoprice select mini v1

title: Gloomhaven Monster All In One Containers

description.text:
New Improved Monster Containers.

The Base holds the 8 Ability Cards (even sleeved)
All necessary standees corresponding to the ability cards.
Extra Monster Stat Cards.

The lid slides on to the base and holds a single stat card. The lid top and the lid bottom will need to be glued together.

Note: If your tolerance printing isn't spot on, I recommend increasing the scale of the base by a very small margin. It is a tight print and on some prints the lid slid on, other times I had to file the edges of the lid base to get it to slide in smoothly.

What you need to print:
For the bases, there are 3 sizes. Base 3, Base 4, and Base 5. The number indicates how many standees can be stack inside it.
Base 3 File: 24 prints
Base 4 File: 2 Prints
Base 5 File: 3 Prints

Lid Bottom. 29 prints

Tor the Lid Top, there are 3 files. 0, 6, 10. If you want to use the containers instead of the came envelopes you will want to use the 6 and 10. If you don't plan to use the containers to manage damage, I recommend just printing out the 0 which is then just a smooth top.

Lid Top 0 File: 1
Lid Top 6 File: 22
Lid Top 10 File: 6

The file breakdown by monster type: All 29 Monster Containers need the Lid Bottom Monster: Base Size, Lid Top Number
Ancient Artillery: 3,6
Archer: 5,6 (Holds Bandits (6), City Guards (6), Inox Guards (6), 2 Stat cards in the base, and one in the lid.
Boss: 5,0 (Holds all Boss Standess 4 standees high, then 12 of the 13 stat cards. 13th stat card kept in the lid)
Cave Bear: 3,6
Cultist: 3,6
Deep Terror: 3,10
Earth Demon: 3,6
Flame Demon: 3,6
Frost Demon: 3,6
Giant Viper: 3,10
Guard: 5,6 (Same fitting as the Archers)

comments.text: I would guess just the base. On a few that I printed, I had to file the edge of the lid bottom piece to get it to slide in. If your machine is not zeroed in on it's tolerance it can be a tight fit if no resizing is done. increasing the base by 1mm would be enough to have the lid slide it smoothly but still shut and stay shut.

description.text:
With the Hornady Lock-N-Load Classic (single stage) press and the provided primer catcher, spent primers would often jump onto the floor while de-capping cases.

With this primer catcher and primer stopper I have decapped over 1000 cases (small and large primers) and every primer dropped right into the trash can. The drop tube on the primer catcher is designed to work with a 1/2" inner diameter tube, but I have not needed to use a tube as long as I have a trash can placed underneath.

The support braces on the primer catcher wrap around the rear beam on the press. The primer stopper should be slid down into the ram before placing your shell holder (you cannot insert from the side like the stock primer arm).

I have also attached a model of the original Hornady primer arm, but 3d printed versions of the original primer arm are not slick or heavy enough to function like the metal original.

Printer:

QIDI X-Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The floor of the Hornady LNL Classic is not flat, so the base of the primer catcher is uneven. You will need supports.

The support brace broke when I printed an earlier version in PLA. This version in PETG has worked very well, even though the support brace has to flex to wrap around the back of the press.

Love your Koma Elektronik Eurorack modular analog synth case so much that you can't bear the thought of marring or scratching the beautiful finish? Don't want to use the little rubber feet? How about making a set of lovely wooden standups instead? My daughter made up the name "standups" because "feet" sound nasty.

Download the .stl file of your liking (face up on the table orientation, or upright) then feed it into your magical cutting machine via the appropriate software. I used Rhino with the print driver to cut on an Epilog Zing 16 40-Watt laser, but your software/driver will vary depending on cutter.

Laser cut two sets of 1/4" baltic birch plywood standups for either face up or upright orientations, then screw them into the case's threaded inserts with M6 screws.

You can also use these files with a CNC router or as a template for cutting on a bandsaw or do it the old fashioned way like your grandmother did with her Eurorack case and use a hand saw!

Hope you enjoy.
Use some sandpaper to remove the caramelized edges if you like. If you need to, you can cut two thinner pieces of stock per standup and laminate them with glue and clamping.

remixed_from.author: DaveGun
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Zero W Case w/ Camera

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Camera Case & Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix from DaveGun. This case is designed to snap together and not require any additional hardware to assemble. It is designed for the Raspberry Pi Zero W (WIFI) although would work with a Raspberry Pi Zero (non-WIFI) if you had the proper adapter to go from micro-USB to USB Type A. The camera module used is the Raspberry Pi Camera v2.

The only ports accessible from the Pi inside the case are the two micro-USB ports (power and input). There is enough room inside the case to use a standard Raspberry Pi Zero Camera Cable, although I would recommend the 40mm camera cable, as it simply looks nicer and is not as cluttered. Amazon has a 2-pack of the 40mm Raspberry Pi Zero Camera Cable for $4.99.

I have two of mine running with the standard camera cable and one running with the 40mm cable and cannot notice a difference once the case is closed. I have had mine running for weeks at a time and never any issues with over-heating. Like DaveGun suggests, I used the Rpi-Cam-Web-Interface (http://elinux.org/RPi-Cam-Web-Interface) and must say that I am impressed at the quality and features provided from open-source software and a RPI Zero.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed my cases in PLA and they snap together very nicely and are quite strong, do not pull apart too easily. I do not see why ABS would not give the same results but have not tried.

For those using a Lulzbot, I printed the cases with the High-Quality-PLA profile as provided by the Lulzbot website.

Assembly

Connect the Raspberry Pi Zero and Camera via the camera cable you decided to use and place the RPi Zero on the "bottom" printed piece. Then place the RPi Camera module on the "top" printed piece and bring the two pieces together until they snap together.
NOTE: If you are using the standard length camera cable, fold the cable nicely as your bring the two pieces together, avoiding kinks in the cable.

The camera case should stand on either side by itself and hold together without issue but the stand is a great option for those that want a little extra balance with their camera.

This is a compact wind powered generator that can fit in a backpack. Designed for a contest for Esso fuels. A stake allows you to set it up anywhere where the ground is soft enough to poke in to it. Designed to be 3d printed simply and with minimal additional parts (and to look cool). Ideally, this will charge a power bank which can be used later to charge up various devices.

There are 7 pieces total to print, along with a few additional parts that can be purchased easily online. You may need to adjust the size of some parts by +/-1% depending on your printer for a snug fit. I also recommend small amounts of glue to make it super solid. It's possible to print without supports but the print will need some clean-up. I used very light support structure during the print mainly to help with where the large gear attaches to the body using a skateboard bearing.

While a 250mL can is great for drinks, it's not the largest wind-catcher, so my design goal was to maximize power output from the windmill by using gears. The small gear which is attached to the DC motor spins twice for every one spin of the larger gear, without adding too much resistance to the main windmill.

The following parts are all that is needed in addtion to the printed parts:

  • (1) Skateboard wheel bearing.

  • (1) Small DC Motor: Here is what I used: http://a.co/c5qgQ75

  • (1) USB power converter; Here is what I used: http://a.co/g9crvt6

  • Scrap Wire

  • Glue (I used Krazy Glue)

I am still doing some testing to see what kind of power it actually generates, but hooking it up to a multimeter you will see that it generates a current!

Quick tips on putting it together once parts are printed:

  1. The "lower arm" for the can holder has a hole through the middle so it can be aligned with the top of the larger gear and glued in place. Simply put a small screwdriver or thick wire through the hole and then through the hole in the top of the large gear, glue in place. This was designed for better printing of the gear and arm, as well as making the option of putting a larger/redesigned windmill on the top of the drive gear if you'd like to change things up while using the same base.

  2. The smallest piece helps 'lock-in' the USB port. it was designed to exactly fit the adapter I listed above. It snaps in below the USB port, I added a few drops of glue to make sure it stays put.

  3. I first attached the wires to the USB adapter, then put the wires through the body and up through the top. once the USB port was in place, I attached the wires to the motor and then placed the motor through the top hole, and put the small gear on it. Once i was sure all electronics were attached and working, I glued the stake in place to finalize it all.

  4. I used a dremel cutting tool to cut the can in half.

Eachine E58 Drone Propeller Repair Part. (updates below)

Having the E58 just a few days... and of course a few bumps in the wall, I sustained some damage, not to the props but to the part assembly holding them together.

Well Eachine gives you a few extra propellers... but...couldn't find an extra part like this thing in the package...go figure.

So.. at first I thought I couldn't get a successful print because of the tiny shapes.. that they would just print deformed.. but I've been modifying the print to compensate for shrinkage and melt.. and I'm starting to see the possibility of having a successful print.

Most likely you will need a few small drills to clean up the print.

By the way ... I'm I the only one that's constantly adjusting for drift on this thing? I've noticed I can get a solid holding position as long as I don't rotate the E58.. but once I rotate.. it needs to be readjusted for drift.

Update: 2/24/18.. Surprisingly this printed better than expected. using a little emery cloth and the right size drill bits.... it was easy to clean up.. and is has lasted more abuse than the original.

For Propeller guards see:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2805529

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a model of the Delta 4 Heavy that I made. Stands almost a foot tall. The model will stand on its own once put together, but I also made a simulated launch pad with mounts to help keep it steady. The second stage easily slides out and is really only held in place by gravity.
I did a little spray paint job on the model just for kicks!

The model does require a little bit of supports. Print vertically, which ever end does not matter. I printed mine with engines and nose cone up.I printed mine using
0.2mm layer height
20% infill
But I think this model will do just fine with a thicker layer height or less infill

The mounts on the launch pad are a bit fragile and break easily, so be careful once printed.

Assembly instructions -
1) Print 3 engine sections, 2 booster tops, 1 core top, 1 second stage, and 4 longerons.
2) The engines should fit snug to the core and booster tops. I did not have to use any glue
3) Lay the boosters and core together on a flat surface. GLUE or WELD the longerons to the model. They do not clip on, so additional adhesive is required.
4) As mentioned above, the model should stand on its own from here (including the 2nd stage). But you can print off the launch pad for added stability

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes
Basic sniper from fortnite.

I honestly have no idea what this should be called. I know it's been done before and I know it's nothing new. I just wanted to finally make one....whatever it is. Plus it's pretty satisfying once you make it, put it together and make a cool ellipse. Works great with PETG or a somewhat flexible filament because it all snaps in place. Also you need to print two sliders, not one. Make sure to put the sliders in their tracks BEFORE you attach the handle to the sliders, otherwise you won't be able to put it together. It's not perfect and it's not beautiful but it's cool and I like it. So if you like it, then go and print it too I guess.

UPDATE I now know it is called a trammel of Archimedes

No

description.text:
This thing contains a set of 28mm scale modern shipping container end pieces for war gaming. They are designed to be combined with cut panels of hobby store flat and corrugated plastic card for quick and easy mass production. The final containers are bottomless to save material, and allow figure access to the container.

Included in the thing are container ends for: Fixed closed, and movable doors, blank and refrigerated style container ends. Additionally a side door and window piece are included to build portable office style containers.

PLEASE NOTE: This thing will NOT provide complete containers. It requires the use of both flat and corrugated plastic card to build finished containers. Assembly and gluing is also required.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Regrettably the STL files are not oriented correctly to load into your slicer and print. Please rotate the pieces so they're flat and face up on your print bed. This is because these pieces were my first attempt at 3D design in Fusion 360.

Assembling Containers from Printed End Caps

Additional materials required are:

  • 1mm corrugated plastic card - for container roof and side panels.
  • 0.5mm flat plastic card - for container edge trim.
  • Plastic glue.

Containers can be built to any length, but more than 12cm long may make them too flexible. Cut your corrugated card into three (top, two sides) desired lengths, each 4.5cm wide. The container pieces will print with a rear slot that will hold the corrugated panels. Glue the corrugated panels into these slots on both ends of the container.

Please note there are also two additional pieces - the office door and window, that are designed to be slotted into holes cut in a side panel, to construct a 'porta office'. See painted example photo.

If you're building a container with the simple end frame, you will also require a piece of corrugated plastic card cut into a square, 40mm wide x 38mm high. This is glued into the frame to provide the container end face.

The container trim is cut from flat 0.5mm plastic card, 4mm wide and the appropriate length. Glue to the panel edges and corners to provide additional strength and rigidity to the finished container.

I print with PLA and use Revell's Liquid Glue for plastics. This will bond the PLA and plastic card together nicely.

Also see photos in thing for reference.

This is a probing system, I use it to auto level my bed using some aluminum tape that I bought at walmart attached to the base the aluminum foil has a ground connector to it and the top lock has 4 screws which run the positive. These are wired to the z min endstop and the usezendstopasprobe setting in marlin is enabled along with autobilinearleveling. I then wrap rubber bands around the top lock and around the side hooks. I have obtained about a .0138 accuracy for repeatability tests over 7 different tests total so it's more accurate than my motors can be at the moment. I am using a cheap chinese gt2560 with the ATmega 1280 on it. Feel free to contact with questions!
Hunt down my youtube next level jank for more information!
Hope this helps people!
--Ryan

Gonna want some extra wires and screws hanging around

This should help people auto level on any surface so that they no longer have any need for aluminum beds although if you are printing on glass I suggest taping the extra friction helps the hotend grip.
This will not harm your bed unless you flash your marlin settings to be normally open and mess up really bad. Even in this case the circuit should just not move below its current position unless you break the connection.

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Nudes Blue Nudes refer to a series of gouaches dÃ©coupÃ©es by Henri Matisse, executed in 1952. They represent female nudes either seated or standing, and are among Matisse's final works in any medium.[1] During the early-to-mid-1940s Matisse was in poor health. Eventually by 1950 he stopped painting in favor of his paper cutouts. The Blue Nudes are a major series' of Matisse's final body of works known as the cutouts. The color blue signified distance and volume to Matisse. Frustrated in his attempts to successfully marry dominant and contrasting tones, the artist was moved to use solid slabs of single color early in his career, a technique that became known as Fauvism. The painted gouache cut-outs that comprise the Blue Nudes were inspired by Matisse's collection of African sculpture and a visit that he made to Tahiti in 1930. It took another twenty years and a period of incapacity after an operation before Matisse synthesized these influences into this seminal series

3)-MEASURE YOUR STUFF:
-Find depth of 8mm holes in parts 5 and save to add to later measurement of distance between opposing faces of part 5 and 7 to give you length to cut shaft.

4)-DRILL NICE HOLES IN YOUR PILOTS, AND CUT YOUR SHAFT:
-Using cut off wheel on grinder Cut one shaft to found length less one sixteenth.
-Drill out all pilot holes for your selection of set screws. Tap holes if necessary.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Nudes Blue Nudes refer to a series of gouaches dÃ©coupÃ©es by Henri Matisse, executed in 1952. They represent female nudes either seated or standing, and are among Matisse's final works in any medium.[1] During the early-to-mid-1940s Matisse was in poor health. Eventually by 1950 he stopped painting in favor of his paper cutouts. The Blue Nudes are a major series' of Matisse's final body of works known as the cutouts. The color blue signified distance and volume to Matisse. Frustrated in his attempts to successfully marry dominant and contrasting tones, the artist was moved to use solid slabs of single color early in his career, a technique that became known as Fauvism. The painted gouache cut-outs that comprise the Blue Nudes were inspired by Matisse's collection of African sculpture and a visit that he made to Tahiti in 1930. It took another twenty years and a period of incapacity after an operation before Matisse synthesized these influences into this seminal series

title: Samsung Gear VR Rechargable HMD Tracking Ball

description.text:
This is a rechargeable light-weight (16g) tracking ball for use on Samsung Gear VR. I use this with the PSMove Service for tracking my head position in Steam VR.

The base of the case can be slid under the front lip of my Samsung Gear VR 2016 model, this makes it easy to remove and doesn't need any velcro etc...

Can be easily removed but is so light I don't noticed it i.e. my gear vr weights 344g vs 360g with the tracking ball (both without my phone attached).

[Edit] Battery life is really good, Feb 18 to March 12 and I still haven't needed to recharge it yet. Been using it for at least 20 hours or more so far

Parts:

  • Adafruit mini lipo charger
  • On/Off DPDT switch I salvaged
  • A 200mAH 3.7v Li-Po 402030 battery
  • Duinotech 5050 RGB LED
  • White Ping-Pong ball

Tools used:

  • Superglue
  • Hot glue gun
  • Soldering Iron
  • Solder
  • Flux pen

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

Case 30% & Lid & Base 100%

Notes:

Software & Settings
Used Simplify 3d default High profile settings. Make sure in Simplify's Process Settings that the LayerTab->Top Solid Layers is 999 and Bottom Solid Layers is 999 also. This will ensure you get a 100% infill and no weird under extrusion. Without that set the ring for the Ping-Pong ball gets hollowed out and will easily separate from the lid.

Material
PLA filament

Infill
30% for the case and 100% for the lid and base clip

Supports
Case - I generated supports in Simplify3d and then added some extra support in the case switch and charger holes.
Lid - I generated supports then added extras support under the centre hole and around the lids edges.

Model Placement
Case - Bottom of of case on bed
Lid - two pegs/posts facing down
Base Clip - 4 pegs/posts facing up

Additions
Didn't need a brim/raft.

description.text:
A sturdy keychain that has a hollow shaft just large enough to insert a rolled up bill (Whatever denomination you choose). The hole in the bottom is a bit smaller than the main shaft so when you put the bill inside, it will expand slightly, lock into place, and never fall out. Bill will be there in an emergency when you really need the cash (Or give it to your kids and don't tell them the secret until you get that call that they're stuck somewhere). The groove near the bottom is just wide enough to insert one of your keys to break off the bottom, revealing the bill in an easy to remove state. The fact that you have to break it, should dissuade you from using it before a real emergency. The bottom is pretty sturdy so it shouldn't break off prematurely. Feel free to modify to give it some more flair. A rocket with engines? Who knows? Be sure to print at 100% fill for maximum heft and durability. I had originally planned to fully encapsulate the bill and use the pause function to insert the bill while printing. Opted against it for 2 reasons:

  1. I had my pause and remove print head clear of the print set incorrectly and my printer made a grinding sound that I never want to hear again
  2. You can give it to friends and they can put their own darned money inside. Maybe they're high rollers and go for a Benjamin Franklin!

Tips on rolling the bill
Start out with a crisp, unfolded bill and roll it carefully without adding creases or wrinkles. Once it is as tight a roll as you can get by hand, lay it flat on a hard surface and apply pressure with your hands while rolling it in the same direction. Stop occasionally while it's still a bit loose to make sure that it's not spilling out the end like a Chinese Yo-Yo. Once you get it nice and tight, it should fit in the 5mm diameter hole in the end and expand enough to keep it from ever falling out.

Basic Components

I designed the basic shape of the keychain in Fusion, I imported the fusion design into Sketchup where I added the shaft and the breakaway groove and finalized the length dimensions. Feel free to edit any of the files to suit your needs. Be careful not to make the support for the breakaway cap too thin or it will likely break off prematurely. The groove needs to be about 2mm to fit most standard key widths for easy removal of the breakaway cap.

comments.text: Did you print it at full size, or can it be scaled in such a way as to be more key chain friendly and still fit a full size bill? Also. what were your print settings? If that's not too much to ask! :D
comments.author: dkoverlord

comments.text:
The current size will fit a tightly rolled bill. I'm sure if you scale it in either direction, you'll have problems unless the shaft and opening sizes remain the same. If you use the same shaft and opening size and make other changes, the groove and support measurements need to be considered. You want the support on the end cap to be thick enough that it's not going to break off easily during normal use, drops onto concrete (Has anyone ever dropped their keys?)
The print settings may be finicky depending on your printer. I used a cheap "Monoprice IIIP" bought off Amazon. I'll grab some screenshots of the print settings from Cura that worked for all of the ones shown in the photos. I'll also add my .gcode and .skp and *.f3d files to the post if anyone is interested. Plate adhesion is important and when I printed the first one, I went to bed and when I went into my office to see the finished product, there was a "Bird nest" on the printer and I found the keychain on the floor nearby. Postmortem indicated that the layers were set too thin which caused the print head to drag on the upper layers, building to the point where it finally broke it off the plate.

author: RadMulRot

title: UDOO x86 Case with SATA SSD/HDD compartment and fan

description.text:
Description

I made this case to protect my Udoo x86 running as Linux home server. This is my first more complex design I made with the open source software FreeCAD (https://www.freecadweb.org/).
There is a compartment for a 63,5 mm ('2,5"') SSD/HDD and a 50x50x15 mm fan should keep the disk and board cool. For better mechanical connections I used insert nuts which I molded into the plastic using an soldering iron.
Currently there are no holes for the GPIO headers beacuse I don't need them right now.

Used Parts

Fan

1x Fan, DC, axial, 12VDC, 50x50x15mm, 21,93m3/h, 30,1dBA
Manufacturer: SUNON
Model No: ME50151V3-000U-A99
https://www.tme.eu/en/details/me50151v3-a99/dc12v-fans/sunon/me50151v3-000u-a99/

Fan connector

To connect the fan to the Udoo board I used the following MOLEX PicoBlade connector and soldered it to the fan wires. The PicoBlade connectors were a bit hard to get, so I've put some order links here too.

1x 3-PIN female Molex PicoBlade Connector, 1,25mm, 125V
Manufacturer: MOLEX
Model No: 510210300
https://www.tme.eu/en/details/mx-51021-0300/raster-signal-connectors-125mm/molex/510210300/

2x contact, female, wire 28AWG, PicoBlade, 1,25mm
Manufacturer: MOLEX
Model No: 006660015
https://www.tme.eu/en/details/mx-06-66-0015/raster-signal-connectors-125mm/molex/006660015/

Insert nuts

For the board: M3x5mm Brass insert nut, closed, internal thread
https://www.banggood.com/100Pcs-M3-x-5mm-Brass-Single-Pass-Knurled-Nuts-Female-Thread-Blind-Hole-Insert-Embedded-Nuts-p-1185240.html

For the fan and the lid: M4x4mm - Brass insert nut, open, internal thread
https://www.banggood.com/100Pcs-M4-x-4mm-Brass-Knurled-Nuts-Insert-Female-Thread-Round-Insert-Embedded-Nuts-p-1184177.html

Screws

Board: 4x M3x6
Fan: 4x M4x20
Lid: 4x M4x8

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

No

description.text:
WARNING: This has not been printed yet, please treat as concept only for now.

Assembled model is for visualisation only. It lacks clearance and is not suitable for printing by itself - if attempting a print, please use version in two halves.

This is an experiment creating a parametric tatting shuttle in OpenSCAD. My grandmother is a keen tatter, and would like me to try replicating the design of some of the shuttles she uses.

This device uses the Splines for OpenSCAD library here to produce smooth curves over the body:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1468725

The shape of these things is terrible for 3d printing - can't print on any angle without support material. You'll want to print with some form of removable or dissolvable support.
Print in two halves and assemble using a glue suitable for your plastic/material. I will be attempting to bond the two halves using acetone.

comments.text: This is cool, and I'm glad my library was useful - thanks for noting it.

title: rc aircraft ceiling mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A ceiling mount for models that allows them to be lowered to the ground without the use of a ladder.
Incorporates a ratchet system for easy lowering and raising.
TEST WITH AT LEAST 3 TIMES THE WEIGHT PLANNED TO MOUNT FROM IT FOR 24 HOURS AT LEAST TO MAKE SURE IT DOESN'T COME LOOSE

Use complete stl for guide on assembly
attach a stretchy spring to the spring pin and the ratchet hook to ensure it doesn't slip

To print (for one bend and one ratchet):
Print axle support 4 times
print axle once
Print lower body 4 times
Upper body twice
Ratchet and axle once
ratchet hook once
spring pin once

To set up
Assemble parts and attach a piece of string completely round the ratchet axle and glue solidly
Screw the ratchet on the wall (with a washer) where you want it.
Screw the bend on the corner of the ceiling and run string through
screw a loop screw directly above where you want the model to hang and run string through
attach string securely onto the model when its on the floor and so it balances
winch model up.

print_settings.Notes:: g.code added for a print ready file for anyone with a Tevo Tarantula (not tornado!!) printer.

description.text:
This is (i hope) a one off method to determine the correct adjustments to be made to your slicer settings, before you print an actual part which requires mating to another, or one which requires dimensional accuracy.

The part itself is simple. it has a set of geometric shapes which shall be used to check the dimensions & cross ref against the design dimensions. (i have added a 22mm hole for a 608 bearing fit as well for those who have one laying around)

the trick to doing this is to layout the parts in a grid layout 1st. i chose a 3x3 grid.
i then manipulated per model settings:
scale on the Y-axis (100% / 102% / 104%) &
Horizontal Expansion on the X-axis (0mm , 0.2mm , 0.4mm)

Print. then next mark or index all while still on the build plate before removing. you wont know which is which if not.
next, check the measurements for each & note down on a piece of paper, ideally in a grid pattern.
check your completed doc to determine which setting to go ahead with.!

Printer Brand:

TEVO

Printer:

Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

g.code added for a print ready file for anyone with a Tevo Tarantula (not tornado!!) printer.

check dimensions

1 - the bore hole is 22mm (for a 608 bearing).
2 - the small OD is 42.2mm
3 - the 2 flat outer edges width is 48mm
4 - the raised circular sections are 2mm/3mm/4mm &5mm respectively
5 - center to center distance between the 2mm & 3mm raised circular sections is 38mm.
6 - center to center distance between the 3mm & 4mm raised circular sections is 32mm

During the renovation of our house I put some ceiling strip in the corner put it's very difficult to miter them in the right angle. Specially if the corners aren't the 90 degress. Maybe I'm too stupid to cut them in the right angle.

We use these similar strips from the hardare store:
https://www.amazon.de/deckenabschlussleisten-Baumarkt/s?ie=UTF8&language=en_GB&page=1&rh=n%3A80084031%2Ck%3Adeckenabschlussleisten

So that's the perfect job for an 3D printer.

As you see on the picture I'm still working at the ceiling. I put for the original Inventor 2018 file for both angles to adjust them for corners.

And the next special part for it is a transition part from these special formed strip into a 25 x 6 mm flat strip.

Have fun and happy printing :-)

title: Holder for Lansky sharpening system rods

description.text:
This is a holder for the lansky sharpening system, to hold your honing hones in place.
It fits 6 rods, which is more than enough.
The remix uses millimeter as a measurement unit. It uses little less plastic as the original.
I also reduced the height of the holders a bit.

The lansky system is really great for sharpening your knifes to a razor blade-like thing!

There are mainly two different types of systems:
The korund system:
http://amzn.to/2EMCYZP

And the diamond set:
http://amzn.to/2GooVXB

I have both of them, they are really great!

Print Settings

Infill: 25%
Layer: 0,2mm
Support: no
Raft: no
Brim: yes
Nozzle: 245°C ( eSun PETG http://amzn.to/2GrlK1n)
Bed: 75°C
Print time: approx. 5,5h on a CR-10 (60mm/sec)

I used the following tape on my CR-10:
http://amzn.to/2zXjJGu
This stuff is really great, no extra glue needed, 100% sticky to the printed parts, which come off really easily, even without destroying the tape.

Extra Tip

Another very hot tip is to use kapton tape! Here you get the glossy finish and perfect adhesion like with the blue tape! Look at this:
200mm Kapton tape: http://amzn.to/2nPggqi

Have fun!

Having never done any 3d modelling before, I went to tinkercad.com to combine the snap lock model with a iphone x case model made by Teece: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2637357 which fits very snugly. title: MAX30100 Finger Clip for Heart rate monitor

description.text:
This object is a finger clip I built to use MAX 30100 Heart Rate and Oxy monitor in my IoT device.
It works very well and has a whole in the middle just to connect your finger with the MAX30100 integrated circuit. This device can be used to read heart rate and blood oxygenation so you can build a complete IoT module to dedicate to this function.

This special device can be used alone or together with an IoT Miniservice. Use some hot glue to fix cable in the right side of the clip.

If you need more information about this project or about IoT miniservices, please visit:

http://www.buonevacanze.org/miniservices_EN.html
or
http://www.buonevacanze.org/IoTHeartSensor.html

From this page you will also find the link to the heart rate sensor project once available.

NOTE: This object is intended for experimental device and MUST not be used to really monitor health conditions. The author is not responsible for any damages caused by the use of this object.

author: Tyros87

description.text: Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Nudes Blue Nudes refer to a series of gouaches dÃ©coupÃ©es by Henri Matisse, executed in 1952. They represent female nudes either seated or standing, and are among Matisse's final works in any medium.[1] During the early-to-mid-1940s Matisse was in poor health. Eventually by 1950 he stopped painting in favor of his paper cutouts. The Blue Nudes are a major series' of Matisse's final body of works known as the cutouts. The color blue signified distance and volume to Matisse. Frustrated in his attempts to successfully marry dominant and contrasting tones, the artist was moved to use solid slabs of single color early in his career, a technique that became known as Fauvism. The painted gouache cut-outs that comprise the Blue Nudes were inspired by Matisse's collection of African sculpture and a visit that he made to Tahiti in 1930. It took another twenty years and a period of incapacity after an operation before Matisse synthesized these influences into this seminal series

description.text:
There is a TV commercial playing here in the U.S., by State Farm, that shows a woman talking to another woman about a suede couch that she says she "just had to have". Later in the commercial, two robbers break-in to steal the couch with one explaining, to the other one, that when he saw the suede couch, he "just had to have it!"

I felt the same way when I first saw this model. Immediately, I said to myself, I have to print this!

My second thought was, when I learned that it was 190mm high, this would make an awesome piggy bank.

The rest, as the saying goes, is history.

I created a plug for the bottom of the bank so that I wouldn't have to destroy this beautiful work of art to get the money out (and thus, making it reusable). The slot in the plug is designed for a penny (so you can twist it and it stays in place). I also added a piece of felt to the bottom to prevent it scratching/damaging any surfaces it was sitting on.

I redesigned the roof, removing the front and back of the dog house and attached them to the base. I wanted a two color dog house (white/red), so splitting these pieces was necessary.

I have only posted the parts that I changed: the base, roof, door, and plug.

EDIT: Had a request to upload the doghouse without a door. I blocked off the door as requested.

Printer:

Hictop 3DP-12

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20% (except for plug - 50%)

Notes:

The only parts that I used support on were the base (because of the hole in the bottom for the plug), the plug, and of course, Snoopy himself (as reddadsteve recommended). I did not use supports for the roof (my printer was able to complete it without the pieces coming loose from the print bed. In order to get the best surface for the roof, I printed as it sits on the dog house, bottom down.

Here are my print times:
Plug - 36 minutes
Base - 10 hours 30 minutes
Roof - 7 hours 29 minutes
Snoopy (head and body) - 4 hours 20 minutes
Ears, nose, eyes, and lettering - 42 minutes
Door - 53 minutes
Collar - 6 minutes
Total: 24 hours 26 minutes

I did nothing to finish off the print other than glue the pieces together and add the piece of felt to the bottom. I did not need to glue the nose, ears, nor eyes as they fit very snugly into the model.

The purpose of this OpenSCAD script is to scale the reference implementation of Ilan E. Moyer's CoreXY system to your desired printing or cutting envelope. The reference implementation claims a 6 inch by 4 inch envelope. See http://corexy.com/ and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22005

Requires OpenSCAD version 2011.12 or greater. Change the xtravel and ytravel variables in the script to set your own envelope. Then render (F5) to make sure everything looks right at that scale. Some key dimensions for scaled components, like belts and shafts, will be reported in the console. Use these for your modified BOM, or adjust the envelope until the component dimensions match what you happen to have on hand. To get 2D cut patterns for the scaled parts, as well as all the other aluminum and acrylic parts, set the as_DXF variable to true, and render with CGAL (F6). Then choose "export as DXF" from the Design menu. The kerf variable lets you alter the design a bit to allow you to cut with something wider than a waterjet, while still being able to nest the aluminum parts. I have not used the DXF output for machining yet. I intend it to be a good starting point for preparing machinable patterns.

it's just flat so it doesn't really matter as far as infill, brim and rafts. I used brim just to make sure it stuck.
Resolution is up to you.

Files for printing

There's two STL files here.
One labeled Babadook is the original one I created, it's tiny in size so you can just resize it to whatever you want.
The second file is babadook-big, it's a larger and thinner version that I printed, it's about 4.75" / 120mm high.
When you're scaling it up make sure you keep X and Y ratios the same as to keep the correct proportions. I keep the sized locked when scaling up and then unlocked it to change the Z thickness and it works fine.
Basically I took a picture, cropped it, cleaned it up and turned it into an STL file for printing. Enjoy

author: m4RT1n

description.text:
I always break my glasses by falling on the ground or sitting on them... I was tired of buying a new pair of glasses every time, so I decided to 3d print them.
Easy task, but first I had to draw them. So I reused the lenses, but redesigned the shape and joints.

Front face has to be printed as flat, I bent it using a little heat from hair dryer after print.
It brings better results, than trying to print it bent with the supports.
Temples are attached using two small pieces of 1.75mm filament, so I could avoid the problem with tiny screws.

Now I have a lot of fancy color combinations, but my favorite shape, so wearing glasses became a fun, not just necessity.

I understand, that everybody needs to adapt it because of different lens shapes, so here is the link to my onshape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/0219baeaf0aa081ffe102801/w/100bef6351060fb6dc6c6895/e/6810e4e1e30d6a3ce9a7bf7b

description.text:
This is a plant watering system (in progress), using a flat base test tube as a water charger unit. The system consists in a spring loaded check valve allowing to engage the charger in a watering station simply by putting it down.

FR -
Je partage un petit système d'arrosage pour plantes sous forme de chargeur, utilisant un tube à essai à base plate. Le système consiste en un clapet anti-retour à ressort, permettant d'enclencher le chargeur sur une station d'arrosage simplement en le posant dessus.

Printer:

µDelta

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

12%

Mechanical parts :

The spring is from a simple pen. The tiny rode is from an old CD-Driver (doesn't have to be the same, anything 2mm diam can do)
This is a 3 parts assembly. First glue the piston, rode and spring together. After sliding it in the head, lock it to the base using the misplugproof mecanism, glue it together.
This valve simply snaps on the tube To refill, unsnap it.

FR-
Le ressort provient d'un stylo. La petite tige métallique vient d'un vieux lecteur CD ( pas besoin d'utiliser la même chose, n'importe quelle tige de 2 mm de diam fera l'affaire)
Il y a 3 parties. D'abord collez la tige et le ressort sur le piston. Après l'avoir emboité dans la partie supérieure, verrouillez le tout sur la partie inférieur en utilisant le détrompeur intégré, collez le tout.
Cette valve s'emboite simplement sur le tube. Pour le remplir à nouveau, déboitez la.

description.text:
NOTE It appears that Thinigiverse is STILL having issues with it customizer functionality so I am also going to also upload an STL for a small bottle and you can use your slicer (or other app) to rescale to fit your need. Also, it might be time to do a write in campaign to Thinigiverse to FIX the Customizer functionality (here is the link to write them: https://www.thingiverse.com/support )! So if you do a download you will get both the code as well as the STL.

So I was cleaning up the shop and came across of these pill bottles I was saving as I hated to see them just fill up a landfill yet what to do then them? Well I have a Shark Tank moment (yes I just coined) and came up with nifty design that Mr. Wonderful would call me dead to world for not giving to him for pennies on the dollar but guess what? I am providing you the STL right here and now to print off on your 3D printer!

Can I ask you for a favor? It's simple, please subscribe to my Open-SCAD Channel (see here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCNfTwYpWGkDcGhvzj4RoRhQ ) to help me keep making these great customizer apps for you guys! :-)

Also check how we made this here: https://youtu.be/8hK157Im2NI as well as We also printed this out on our BIQU Magician Lipstick-Sized Delta Rostock 3D Printer(see more here: http://amzn.to/2sBRxL1)

Now this is a customizer (so lets hope Thingiverse has this fixed) and you adapt this just about any pill bottle size! Oh what do you do with it, store things what else:-) Yes we makers can be part pack rat so you can maximize the space in each bottle and I know you can't get your fingers down there to get the screws (or what ever) out, so you just pull up on the top and bingo-bango everything comes up!

If your looking for a new printer, check these out as it helps me to keep creating great new designs to post here on thingiverse!

Amazing BIG Kit printer......: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-tronxy-x5s-high-precision-large-scale-3d-printer/
Original Gearbest version...: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-cr-10-super-large-3d-printer/
Best Deals on a Creality......: http://diy3dtech.com/creality-cr-10-best-deals/
Have you been bitten..........: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-tevo-black-widow-3d-printer-kit/
Have you seen this..............: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-tronxy-x1-desktop-3d-printer/
Best Small Kit Deal..............: http://diy3dtech.com/tevo-tarantula/
Creality CR-10 Killer.............: http://diy3dtech.com/gearbest-jgaurora-a5-updated-high-accuracy-3d-printer/
Better then Monoprice Mini: http://diy3dtech.com/geeetech-e180-mini-3d-printer/

Major Favor: if you make one of these please post the Make and share it with the community :-) .

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)! .

description.text:
A simple tool holder for a vinyl cutter.

I have a Roland compatible vinyl cutter and several tools but nowhere to keep them.
This simple holder solves that problem. i used some neodymium magnets but could just as easily have used double sided tape or hot melt glue.

Use any print settings that make you happy.
I used 10% infill with 1.2mm perimeters PLA (which means 100% infill in reality).

25 minute print time @ 60mm/s
I use 25mm*2.5mm neodim-magnet and 1/4-3/8 adapter

NOTE: THE CODE ONLY WORK WITH SPARKMAKER!!!

Hi, I'm investigating the Trigorilla-Pro ESP01 Port.

My printer have a v1.4.0RC23/P3 firmware,,,,

It port is for a ESP01 ESP8266 wifi module.

The Anycubic on Boot talk to wifi module whit AT commands at 115200bps, send a AT command to switch at 2.250.000Bps and open UDP server in port 3000.

This is a snif trafic on port, commands send from Printer.

Boot printer and it send at 115.200 bauds:
⸮⸮⸮⸮⸮⸮AT+UART_CUR=2250000,8,1,0,0

  • "?????" scrap data
  • AT+UART_CUR=2250000,8,1,0,0 Set a ESP8266 to change at 2.250.000 bps

Then at 2.250.000 bauds printer send:
AT+CIPSTART=4,"UDP","192.168.1.110",8080,3000,2

  • Set a ESP8266 a UDP server at port 3000 in muticonnection mode
  • IP 192.168.1.110 and port 8080 in UDP protocol are Irrelevant.
  • (command AT+CWMODE=1 not apears but is necessari send before to accept that command)

More thinks:
If I send via Cura console to printer some commands like:

Command via cura console:
M9005 '"ssid","password"'
And receive via ESP8266 port the string:
AT+CWSAP="ssid","password”,5,3
Means in AT command, put ESP8266 in mode AP with SSID=SSID and 3=WPA_TKIP password="password", 5=5 channel at 2,4Ghz.

Commnad via cura console:
M9003 '"ssid","password"'
And receive via ESP8266 port the string:
AT+CWJAP="ssid","password"
Means in AT command, put ESP8266 in Station mode and connect to wireless SSID=SSID and password="password"

Ok, go to make some probes.
I check the printer AT commands in ESP8266 module with AT firmwares and work fine.
Now, connect the ESP8266 to printer and it not work properly. I thint that some commands are needed to perfom setup operation correctly.

Workaround:
Program ESP8266 with Arduino IDE.
Simple program,

  • Puts a UART in 2.250.000dbs
  • Connects to my wirelees network in DHCP
  • Open TCP server at port 2000 (such a telnet server)
  • Create a trasparent bridge between Server <> UART

Results:

ESP8266 now ignoring the printer string or commands (fixed configuration no AT commands to execute *TO DO) and sent it to wireless connection.

Connect my PC to TCP 2000 port:
receibed some strings from boot time in console

Now I send some strings to tcp console in AT format commands and responses:

Send:
+IPD,4,3:M20
NOTE: +IPD,4,3: < is a AT command that indicates that he receibed in channel stream 4, 3 bytes with string "M30" (M30 command Marling is a list of SD files)

Reply:
Begin file list
ANYCUBIC 0=4,12
.Spotlight-V100 0
.fseventsd 0,14
Models 0ND=4,10
prova.gcode 615
AI3M_Print.gcode 4641914
End file list15
ok L:6SEND=4,8

Printer send me a SD file list.
ANYCUBIC < Name of SD
Models < Folder
*.gcode are gcode files, number indicates bytes of file
WOW it's working!!!

Some other commands.....
Send:
+IPD,4,4:M300
Reply:
ok N:0SEND=4,8
"Printer beeps"

Now I send a printer to print a SD file.
Investigating google i found a M6030 command, open file and print it, check it:

Send:
+IPD,4,19:M6030 'prova.gcode'
Reply:
ok N:0SEND=4,8

prova.gcode file contais only 1 marlin command M300, printer open file and execute it, and printer beeps.

TO DO...

Take advantage of M9005 and M9003 commands
Implent rudimentary code to execute AT commands sended by M9005 and M9003 instructions, set wireles mode.
Printer haven't a wireless menu, but is simple to set it, create a text file with gcode commands M9003 o M9005 to set it.

Investigate to implment in ESP8266 optoprint protocol to make possible thtat CURA lint to ESP8266 su as a optoprint server.

That's all at the moment, avances

Please any information are well become, is you have any question please ask me.
Note: The English language is not my mother tongue, my English level is quite low
I speak Catalonian and Spanish lenguage.

What is it?

This is a small recycling bin that looks like the Windows 10 recycling bin on the desktop.
The dimensions are 116x126x150mm. You can print it as a multicolor or singlecolor print.

How to print?

If printed as a singlecolor print you have to print the bin and the arrows separately and glue them afterwards. I designed an alignment tool for easy alignment before glueing it together.
The arrows for the multicolor print are smaller so that you can print it without support.

Remarks

If you have problems with printing or other remarks to the design, please let me know.
